one-stop source for medical information on nearly 1,700 cine. The Gale Encyclopedia of Medicine 2 includes a

ments, including high-profile diseases such as AIDS, traditional Chinese medicine to homeopathy and from
Alzheimer’s disease,cancer,and heart attack. This ency- meditation to aromatherapy.

ADVISORY BOARD
A number of experts in the library and medical communities provided invaluable assistance in the formulation of this ency-
clopedia.

--- Chunk 15 ---
Our advisory board performed a myriad of duties,from defining the scope of coverage to reviewing individual
entries for accuracy and accessibility. The editor would like to express her appreciation to them.

--- صفحة 15 ---
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:41 PM Page 1
A
Abdominal aorta ultrasound see Abdominal While pelvic ultrasoundis widely known and com-
monly used for fetal monitoring during pregnancy,
ultrasound
ultrasound is also routinely used for general abdominal
Abdominal aortic aneurysm see Aortic imaging. It has great advantage over x-ray imaging tech-
aneurysm nologies in that it does not damage tissues with ionizing
radiation.

--- Chunk 34 ---
Ultrasound is also generally far better than
Abdominal hernia see Hernia
plain x rays at distinguishing the subtle variations of soft
Abdominal thrust see Heimlich maneuver tissue structures, and can be used in any of several
modes,depending on the need at hand.
As an imaging tool,abdominal ultrasound generally
is warranted for patients afflicted with:chronic or acute
abdominal pain; abdominal trauma; an obvious or sus-
pected abdominal mass; symptoms of liver disease,pan-
Abdominal ultrasound creatic disease, gallstones, spleen disease, kidney dis-

Abortion, habitual see Recurrent
At birth,the problem is obvious,because the base of
the umbilical cord at the navel will bulge or, in worse miscarriage
cases,contain viscera (internal organs). Before birth,an
ultrasound examination may detect the problem. It is
always necessary in children with one birth defect to look
for others,because birth defects are usually multiple.

highly controversial nature of this procedure. A contro- Aftercare

D&X typically does not require an overnight hospi-
fetus is viable,or able to survive outside of the woman’s
tal stay,so a follow up appointment may be scheduled to
body. A specific area of controversy with D&X is that
monitor the woman for any complications.
fetal death does not occur until after most of the fetal
body has exited the uterus. Several states have taken
legal action to limit or ban D&X and many physicians

restrict the availability of this procedure to women seek- With all abortion,the later in pregnancy an abortion

Abortion, selective
Individuals seeking an abortion for any reason
should consider the ethical implications whether it be
Definition
because the fetus is not the preferred sex or because the
Selective abortion, also known as selective reduc- fetus would be born with a severe birth defect.
tion, refers to choosing to abort a fetus, typically in a
multi-fetal pregnancy,to decrease the health risks to the
Aftercare
mother in carrying and giving birth to more than one or
two babies,and also to decrease the risk of complications Counseling should continue after the abortion

Description
Meghan M. Gourley
Very early abortions
Abortion, spontaneous see Miscarriage
Between five and seven weeks,a pregnancy can be
ended by a procedure called menstrual extraction. This
procedure is also sometimes called menstrual regulation,
mini-suction,or preemptive abortion. The contents of the
uterus are suctioned out through a thin (3-4 mm) plastic
tube that is inserted through the undilated cervix.

--- Chunk 83 ---
Suction
Abortion, therapeutic
is applied either by a bulb syringe or a small pump.

simply expelled from the body.

Abortion,

•The procedure may require multiple visits to the doctor.
•Bleeding after the abortion lasts longer than after a sur-
gical abortion.
•The woman may see the contents of her womb as it is
expelled.
Two different medications can be used to bring about
an abortion. Methotrexate (Rheumatrex) works by stop-
ping fetal cells from dividing which causes the fetus to die.
On the first visit to the doctor,the woman receives
an injection of methotrexate.

--- Chunk 87 ---
On the second visit,about
a week later, she is given misoprostol (Cytotec), an
oxygenated unsaturated cyclic fatty acid responsible for
various hormonal reactions such as muscle contraction
(prostaglandin), that stimulates contractions of the
uterus. Within two weeks, the woman will expel the
contents of her uterus,ending the pregnancy. A follow-
up visit to the doctor is necessary to assure that the
abortion is complete.
With this procedure, a woman will feel cramping
and may feel nauseated from the misoprostol. This
combination of drugs is 90-96% effective in ending
pregnancy.
Mifepristone(RU-486),which goes by the brand
name Mifeprex,works by blocking the action of prog-
brand of birth control pill.

Description
There are two types of abscesses,septic and sterile.
Most abscesses are septic,which means that they are the
result of an infection. Septic abscesses can occur any-
where in the body. Only a germ and the body’s immune
response are required. In response to the invading germ,
white blood cells gather at the infected site and begin
producing chemicals called enzymes that attack the germ
by digesting it. These enzymes act like acid,killing the
germs and breaking them down into small pieces that can
be picked up by the circulation and eliminated from the
body. Unfortunately, these chemicals also digest body
tissues. In most cases,the germ produces similar chemi-
cals.

--- Chunk 104 ---
The result is a thick,yellow liquid—pus—contain-
ing digested germs, digested tissue, white blood cells,
and enzymes.
An abscess is the last stage of a tissue infection that Causes and symptoms
begins with a process called inflammation. Initially,as
Many different agents cause abscesses. The most
the invading germ activates the body’s immune system,
common are the pus-forming (pyogenic) bacteria like
several events occur:
Staphylococcus aureus,which is nearly always the cause
•Blood flow to the area increases.
of abscesses under the skin. Abscesses near the large
•The temperature of the area increases due to the bowel,particularly around the anus,may be caused by
increased blood supply. any of the numerous bacteria found within the large
bowel.

--- Chunk 105 ---
Brain abscesses and liver abscesses can be caused
•The area swells due to the accumulation of water,blood,
by any organism that can travel there through the circula-
and other liquids.
tion. Bacteria, amoeba, and certain fungi can travel in
•It turns red. this fashion. Abscesses in other parts of the body are
caused by organisms that normally inhabit nearby struc-
•It hurts,because of the irritation from the swelling and
tures or that infect them. Some common causes of specif-
the chemical activity.
ic abscesses are:
These four signs—heat,swelling,redness,and pain—
characterize inflammation. •skin abscesses by normal skin flora

to liquid, and an abscess forms.

Diagnosis
Prognosis
The common findings of inflammation—heat,red-
ness, swelling, and pain—easily identify superficial Once the abscess is properly drained,the prognosis
abscesses. Abscesses in other places may produce only is excellent for the condition itself.

--- Chunk 114 ---
The reason for the
generalized symptoms such as fever and discomfort. If abscess (other diseases the patient has) will determine
the patient’s symptoms and physical examinationdo not the overall outcome. If, on the other hand, the abscess
help,a physician may have to resort to a battery of tests to ruptures into neighboring areas or permits the infectious
14 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
ssecbA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:41 PM Page 14
--- صفحة 29 ---
agent to spill into the bloodstream,serious or fatal conse-
quences are likely. Abscesses in and around the nasal
sinuses,face,ears,and scalp may work their way into the
brain. Abscesses within an abdominal organ such as the
liver may rupture into the abdominal cavity. In either
case,the result is life threatening.

--- Chunk 115 ---
Blood poisoningis a
term commonly used to describe an infection that has
spilled into the blood stream and spread throughout the
body from a localized origin. Blood poisoning,known to
physicians as septicemia,is also life threatening.
Of special note,abscesses in the hand are more seri-
ous than they might appear. Due to the intricate structure
and the overriding importance of the hand, any hand
infection must be treated promptly and competently.
Prevention
Infections that are treated early with heat (if superfi-
cial) or antibiotics will often resolve without the forma-
tion of an abscess. It is even better to avoid infections
altogether by taking prompt care of open injuries,partic-
ularly puncture wounds.

--- Chunk 116 ---
Bites are the most dangerous of
all,even more so because they often occur on the hand.
Resources
BOOKS
Bennett,J. Claude,and Fred Plum,eds. Cecil Textbook of Med-
icine.Philadelphia:W. B. Saunders Co.,1996.

Stephen McPhee,et al. Stamford:Appleton & Lange,1995.
Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine.Ed. Anthony S. blood cells that were carried to the area to fight the infec-
Fauci,et al. New York:McGraw-Hill,1997. tion. Abscesses are often found in the soft tissue under
the skin,such as the armpit or the groin. However,they
J. Ricker Polsdorfer,MD may develop in any organ,and are commonly found in
the breast and gums.

--- Chunk 117 ---
Abscesses are far more serious and
Abscess drainage see Abscess incision and call for more specific treatment if they are located in
drainage deep organs such as the lung,liver or brain.
Because the lining of the abscess cavity tends to
interfere with the amount of the drug that can penetrate
the source of infection from the blood,the cavity itself
may require draining. Once an abscess has fully formed,
Abscess incision & drainage it often does not respond to antibiotics. Even if the

in any organ,such as the liver.

Nancy Ross-Flanigan Diagnosis
Diagnosis of achalasia begins with a careful medical
Acetylsalicylic acid see Aspirin

Achalasia

exerted by the esophageal sphincter.

vents normal swallowing.

see its constriction at the sphincter.

•Endoscopy.

KEY TERMS
Botulinum toxin—Any of a group of potent bacte-
rial toxins or poisons produced by different strains
of the bacterium Clostridium botulinum. The tox-
ins cause muscle paralysis.
Dysphagia—Difficulty in swallowing.
Endoscopy—A test in which a viewing device and
a light source are introduced into the esophagus by
means of a flexible tube. Endoscopy permits visual
inspection of the esophagus for abnormalities.
Esophageal manometry—A test in which a thin
tube is passed into the esophagus to measure the
degree of pressure exerted by the muscles of the
esophageal wall.

--- Chunk 149 ---
Esophageal sphincter—A circular band of muscle
that closes the last few centimeters of the esopha-
gus and prevents the backward flow of stomach
contents.
Esophagomyotomy—A surgical incision through
the muscular tissue of the esophagus.
Esophagus—The muscular tube that leads from the Description
back of the throat to the entrance of the stomach.
Achondroplasia is one of a number of chondodystro-
Peristalsis—The coordinated, rhythmic wave of phies,in which the development of cartilage,and there-
smooth muscle contraction that forces food fore,bone is disturbed. The disorder appears in approxi-
through the digestive tract. mately one in every 10,000 births. Achondroplasia is
Reflux—An abnormal backward or return flow of usually diagnosed at birth, owing to the characteristic
a fluid.

--- Chunk 150 ---
appearance of the newborn.
Normal bone growth depends on the production of
cartilage (a fibrous connective tissue). Over time,calci-
um is deposited within the cartilage,causing it to hard-
Prevention
en and become bone. In achondroplasia,abnormalities
of this process prevent the bones (especially those in
There is no known way to prevent achalasia.
the limbs) from growing as long as they normally
should,at the same time allowing the bones to become
Resources

Achondroplasia Causes and symptoms
Achondroplasia is caused by a genetic defect. It is a
Definition

Achondroplasia is the most common cause of defect will display all the symptoms of the disorder. A

ing loss. The disease does not affect either mental capac-

Causes and symptoms
Acid reflux see Heartburn The exact cause of acne is unknown. Several risk
factors have been identified:
Acidosis see Respiratory acidosis; Renal
•Age. Due to the hormonal changes they experience,
tubular acidosis; Metabolic acidosis
teenagers are more likely to develop acne.
•Gender.

--- Chunk 165 ---
Boys have more severe acne and develop it
more often than girls.
•Disease. Hormonal disorders can complicate acne in
Acne girls.
•Heredity. Individuals with a family history of acne have
Definition
greater susceptibility to the disease.
Acne is a common skin disease characterized by
•Hormonal changes. Acne can flare up before menstrua-
pimples on the face,chest,and back. It occurs when the
tion,during pregnancy,and menopause.
pores of the skin become clogged with oil, dead skin
•Diet. No foods cause acne,but certain foods may cause
cells,and bacteria.

•Drugs. Acne can be a side effect of drugs including

Acne vulgaris,the medical term for common acne,is ceptives,and anabolic steroids.

--- Chunk 168 ---
Diagnosis
Moderate and severe inflammatory types of acne
result after the plugged follicle is invaded by Propioni- Acne patients are often treated by family doctors.
bacterium acnes, a bacteria that normally lives on the Complicated cases are referred to a dermatologist,a skin
24 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
encA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:41 PM Page 24
--- صفحة 39 ---
disease specialist,or an endocrinologist,a specialist who
treats diseases of the body’s endocrine (hormones and
glands) system.
Acne has a characteristic appearance and is not diffi-
cult to diagnose. The doctor takes a complete medical
history,including questions about skin care,diet,factors
causing flare-ups,medication use,and prior treatment.

--- Chunk 169 ---
Physical examination includes the face, upper neck,
chest,shoulders,back,and other affected areas. Under
good lighting,the doctor determines what types and how
many blemishes are present,whether they are inflamed,
whether they are deep or superficial,and whether there is
scarring or skin discoloration.
In teenagers, acne is often found on the forehead,
nose,and chin. As people get older,acne tends to appear
towards the outer part of the face. Adult women may
have acne on their chins and around their mouths. The
elderly may develop whiteheads and blackheads on the
upper cheeks and skin around the eyes.
Laboratory tests are not done unless the patient
appears to have a hormonal disorder or other medical
problem. In this case,blood analyses or other tests may
be ordered.

--- Chunk 170 ---
Most insurance plans cover the costs of diag-
nosing and treating acne.
Treatment
Acne treatment consists of reducing sebum produc-
tion,removing dead skin cells,and killing bacteria with
topical drugs and oral medications. Treatment choice
depends upon whether the acne is mild, moderate, or
severe.
Drugs
TOPICAL DRUGS. Treatment for mild noninflamma- mycin), are also used. These drugs may be used for
tory acne consists of reducing the formation of new months to years to achieve disease control.
comedones with topical tretinoin,benzoyl peroxide,ada-
After washing with mild soap,the drugs are applied
palene,or salicylic acid.

--- Chunk 171 ---
Tretinoin is especially effective
alone or in combination, once or twice a day over the
because it increases turnover (deathand replacement) of
entire affected area of skin. Possible side effects include
skin cells. When complicated by inflammation,topical
mild redness,peeling,irritation,dryness,and an increased
antibiotics may be added to the treatment regimen.
sensitivity to sunlight that requires use of a sunscreen.
Improvement is usually seen in two to four weeks.

Topical medications are available as cream, gel,

lotion, or pad preparations of varying strengths.

Acne rosacea see Rosacea

•use noncomedogenic makeup and moisturizers

•heavy sweating

People with acromegaly have more skin tags,or out-
growths of tissue,than normal.

--- Chunk 218 ---
This increase in skin tags
is also associated with the development of growths,
called polyps,within the large intestine that may eventu-
ally become cancerous. Patients with acromegaly often
suffer from headaches and arthritis. The various
swellings and enlargements throughout the body may
press on nerves,causing sensations of local tingling or
burning,and sometimes result in muscle weakness.
The most common cause of this disorder (in 90% of
patients) is the development of a noncancerous tumor with-
in the pituitary,called a pituitary adenoma. These tumors
are the source of the abnormal release of GH. As these
tumors grow,they may press on nearby structures within the
brain,causing headaches and changes in vision.

--- Chunk 219 ---
As the ade-
noma grows,it may disrupt other pituitary tissue,interfering
with the release of other hormones. These disruptions may
be responsible for changes in the menstrual cycle of
women,decreases in the sexual drive in men and women,
and the abnormal production of breast milk in women. In
rare cases,acromegaly is caused by the abnormal produc-
tion of GHRH,which leads to the increased production of
increase of IGF-1 (3-10 times above the normal level) are
GH. Certain tumors in the pancreas,lungs,adrenal glands,
useful. These results,however,must be carefully inter-

KEY TERMS
Adenoma—A type of noncancerous (benign)
tumor that often involves the overgrowth of certain
cells found in glands.
Gland—A collection of cells that releases certain
chemicals, or hormones, that are important to the
functioning of other organs or body systems.
Hormone—A chemical produced in one part of
the body that travels to another part of the body in
order to exert an effect.

--- Chunk 223 ---
Hypothalamus—A structure within the brain
responsible for a large number of normal functions
throughout the body, including regulating sleep,
temperature, eating, and sexual development. The
hypothalamus also regulates the functions of the
require additional treatment with medication. Bromocrip-
pituitary gland by directing the pituitary to stop or
tine (Parlodel) is a medication that can be taken by mouth,
start production of its hormones.
while octreotide (Sandostatin) must be injected every eight
hours. Both of these medications are helpful in reducing Pituitary—A gland located at the base of the brain
GH production,but must often be taken for life and pro- that produces a number of hormones, including
duce their own unique side effects.

Actinomycosis is a relatively rare infection occurring
in one out of 300,000(1/300,000) people per year. It is
characterized by the presence of a lump or mass that often Biopsy—The process which removes a sample of

the rest are in the pelvis,heart,and brain. Men are three
times more likely to develop actinomycosis than women.

Today,there are mil-
lions of patients who attest to its effectiveness,and near-
ly 9,000 practitioners in all 50 states.
Acupressure is practiced as a treatment by Chinese
medicine practitioners and acupuncturists,as well as by
massage therapists. Most massage schools in American
include acupressure techniques as part of their bodywork
programs. Shiatsu massage is very closely related to acu-
pressure,working with the same points on the body and
the same general principles,although it was developed
over centuries in Japan rather than in China. Reflexology
is a form of bodywork based on acupressure concepts.

--- Chunk 238 ---
Jin Shin Do is a bodywork technique with an increasing
number of practitioners in America that combines acu-
pressure and shiatsu principles with qigong, Reichian
theory,and meditation.
Acupressure and Chinese medicine
Chinese medicine views the body as a small part of
the universe,subject to laws and principles of harmony
and balance. Chinese medicine does not make as sharp a
destinction as Western medicine does between mind and
body. The Chinese system believes that emotions and
mental states are every bit as influential on disease as
purely physical mechanisms,and considers factors like
work,environment,and relationships as fundamental to a
patient’s health. Chinese medicine also uses very different
symbols and ideas to discuss the body and health.

--- Chunk 239 ---
While
Western medicine typically describes health as mainly
physical processes composed of chemical equations and
reactions,the Chinese use ideas like yin and yang,chi,
and the organ system to describe health and the body.
Everything in the universe has properties of yin and
yang. Yin is associated with cold,female,passive,down-
ward,inward,dark,wet. Yang can be described as hot,
male, active, upward, outward, light, dry, and so on.
Nothing is either completely yin or yang. These two prin-
ciples always interact and affect each other,although the
body and its organs can become imbalanced by having
either too much or too little of either.
Chi (pronounced chee,also spelled qior kiin Japan-
ese shiatsu) is the fundamental life energy.

--- Chunk 240 ---
It is found in
food,air,water,and sunlight,and it travels through the
body in channels called meridians. There are 12 major

Acute kidney failure
Acupuncture is generally a very safe procedure. If a
patient is in doubt about a medical condition,more than
Definition
one physician should be consulted. Also,a patient should
always feel comfortable and confident that their Acute kidney failure occurs when illness,infection,

ney failure.

Dissociation—A reaction to trauma in which the
Adult respiratory distress syndrome mind splits off certain aspects of the trauma from

Acute stress disorder life-threatening event.

50 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
noitciddA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:41 PM Page 50
--- صفحة 65 ---
A 1997 Harvard study found that an estimated 15.4
million Americans suffered from a gambling addiction.
Over half that number (7.9 million) were adolescents.
Causes and symptoms
Addiction to substances results from the interaction
of several factors:
Drug chemistry
Some substances are more addictive than others,
either because they produce a rapid and intense change in
mood; or because they produce painful withdrawal
symptoms when stopped suddenly.
Genetic factor
Some people appear to be more vulnerable to addic-
tion because their body chemistry increases their sensi-
tivity to drugs.

--- Chunk 316 ---
Some forms of substance abuse and
dependenceseem to run in families; and this may be the
result of a genetic predisposition,environmental influ-
ences,or a combination of both.
Brain structure and function
Using drugs repeatedly over time changes brain
structure and function in fundamental and long-lasting
ways. Addiction comes about through an array of
changes in the brain and the strengthening of new memo-
ry connections. Evidence suggests that those long-lasting
brain changes are responsible for the distortions of cog-
nitive and emotional functioning that characterize
addicts, particularly the compulsion to use drugs.

--- Chunk 317 ---
Although the causes of addiction remain the subject of Individual development
ongoing debate and research,many experts now consider
Before the 1980s,the so-called addictive personality
addiction to be a brain disease: a condition caused by
was used to explain the development of addiction. The
persistent changes in brain structure and function. How-
addictive personality was described as escapist,impul-
ever, having this brain disease does not absolve the
sive, dependent, devious, manipulative, and self-cen-
addict of responsibility for his or her behavior,but it does
tered. Many doctors now believe that these character
explain why many addicts cannot stop using drugs by
traits develop in addicts as a result of the addiction,
sheer force of will alone.

--- Chunk 318 ---
rather than the traits being a cause of the addiction.
Social learning Diagnosis
Social learning is considered the most important sin- In addition to a preoccupation with using and
gle factor. It includes patterns of use in the addict’s fami- acquiring the abused substance,the diagnosis of addic-
ly or subculture,peer pressure,and advertising or media tion is based on five criteria:
influence. •loss of willpower
•harmful consequences
Availability •unmanageable lifestyle
Inexpensive or readily available tobacco,alcohol,or •tolerance or escalation of use
drugs produce marked increases in rates of addiction. •withdrawal symptoms upon quitting

Bill Asenjo,MS,CRC Aldosterone, also produced by the adrenal cortex,
plays a central role in maintaining the appropriate pro-
portions of water and salts in the body. When this bal-
ance is upset,the volume of blood circulating throughout
the body will fall dangerously low, accompanied by a
Addison’s disease drop in blood pressure.
Addison’s disease is also called primary adrenocorti-
Definition
cal insufficiency. In other words,some process interferes
Addison’s disease is a disorder involving disrupted directly with the ability of the adrenal cortex to produce
functioning of the part of the adrenal gland called the its hormones. Levels of both cortisol and aldosterone
cortex.

--- Chunk 328 ---
This results in decreased production of two drop, and numerous functions throughout the body are
important chemicals (hormones) normally released by disrupted.
the adrenal cortex:cortisol and aldosterone.
Addison’s disease occurs in about four in every
100,000 people. It strikes both men and women of all ages.
Description
Causes and symptoms

medulla. Each of these parts of the adrenal gland is cortex. In about 70% of all cases, this atrophy is
responsible for producing different types of hormones.

Adenovirus infections are rarely fatal. Most patients
recover fully. Adjustment disorders are very common and can
affect anyone,regardless of gender,age,race,or lifestyle.

--- Chunk 356 ---

An adjustment disorder is a debilitating reaction, •vandalism

Diagnosis
Diagnosis for adrenal cancer usually begins with
blood tests to evaluate the hormone levels. These hor-
mones include epinephrine,cortisol,and testosterone. It
also includes magnetic resonance imaging,and com-
Adrenal gland scan
puted tomography scansto determine the extent of the
disease. Urine and blood tests can be done to detect the Definition
high levels of hormone secreted by the tumor.
The adrenal gland scan is a nuclear medicine evalua-
tion of the medulla (inner tissue) of the adrenal gland.

Aftercare Adrenocortical insufficiency see Addison’s
disease
Patients stay in the hospital for various lengths of
time after adrenalectomy. The longest hospital stays are
required for open surgery using an anterior approach;
hospital stays of about three days are indicated for open
surgery using the posterior approach or for laparoscopic
adrenalectomy.

--- Chunk 389 ---

Diagnosis
KEY TERMS
People who suffer from panic attacks should discuss
the problem with a physician.

--- Chunk 438 ---
The doctor can diagnose
the underlying panic or anxiety disorder and make sure Benzodiazepines—A group of tranquilizers often
the symptoms aren’t related to some other underlying used to treat anxiety.
medical condition. Desensitization—A treatment for phobias which
The doctor makes the diagnosis of agoraphobia involves exposing the phobic person to the feared
based primarily on the patient’s description of his or her situation. It is often used in conjunction with
symptoms. The person with agoraphobia experiences relaxation techniques.
anxiety in situations where escape is difficult or help is Phobia—An intense and irrational fear of a specif-
unavailable—or in certain situations,such as being alone. ic object, activity, or situation.

--- Chunk 439 ---
While many people are somewhat apprehensive in these
situations,the hallmark of agoraphobia is that a person’s
active avoidance of the feared situation impairs his or her
ability to work,socialize,or otherwise function. “Panic Disorder—Panic Attacks and Agoraphobia.”American
Family Physician52,no. 7 (15 Nov. 1995):2067-8.

Inquiries,5600 Fishers Lane,Room 15C-05,Rockville,
attacks in progress with certain tranquilizers called ben-
MD 20857. (888) 826-9438. <http://www.nimh.nih.gov>.
zodiazepines, such as alprazolam (Xanax) or clon-
azepam (Klonipin).
Robert Scott Dinsmoor
The mainstay of treatment for agoraphobia and other
phobias is cognitive behavioral therapy. A specific tech- Agranulocytosis see Neutropenia
nique that is often employed is called desensitization.

--- Chunk 441 ---
The patient is gradually exposed to the situation that usu-
ally triggers fear and avoidance, and, with the help of
breathing or relaxation techniques,learns to cope with
the situation. This helps break the mental connection
AIDS
between the situation and the fear, anxiety, or panic.
Patients may also benefit from psychodynamically ori-
Definition
ented psychotherapy, discussing underlying emotional
conflicts with a therapist or support group. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is an
infectious disease caused by the human immunodeficien-
cyvirus (HIV). It was first recognized in the United States
Prognosis
in 1981.

--- صفحة 97 ---
The HIV antigens are attached by blotting to a nylon or
nitrocellulose filter. The patient’s serum is reacted against
the filter,followed by treatment with developing chemi-
cals that allow HIV antibody to show up as a colored
patch or blot. A commercially produced Western blot test
for HIV-1 is now available.

--- Chunk 494 ---
It consists of a prefabricated
strip that is incubated with a sample of the patient’s blood
serum and the developing chemicals. About nine different
HIV-1 proteins can be detected in the blots.
When used in combination with ELISA testing,
Western blot testing is 99.9% specific. It can,however,
yield false negatives in patients with very early HIV
infection and in those infected by HIV-2. In some
patients the Western blot yields indeterminate results.
IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE ASSAY (IFA). This method
is sometimes used to confirm ELISA results instead of
Western blotting.

--- Chunk 495 ---
An IFA test detects the presence of
HIV antibody in a sample of the patient’s serum by mix-
ing HIV antigen with a fluorescent chemical,adding the
blood sample,and observing the reaction under a micro-
scope with ultraviolet light.

It is important to note that persons with normal liv-
Description ers may have slightly elevated levels of ALT. This is a
normal finding.
The alanine aminotransferase test (ALT) can reveal
liver damage. It is probably the most specific test for
liver damage. However,the severity of the liver damage Michael V.

--- Chunk 525 ---
Zuck,PhD
is not necessarily shown by the ALT test, since the
Alanine aminotransferase test see Liver
amount of dead liver tissue does not correspond to higher
ALT levels. Also, patients with normal, or declining, function tests
ALT levels may experience serious liver damage without
Albers-Schönberg disease see
an increase in ALT.
Osteopetroses
Nevertheless, ALT is widely used, and useful,
because ALT levels are elevated in most patients with
liver disease. Although ALT levels do not necessarily
indicate the severity of the damage to the liver,they may
indicate how much of the liver has been damaged. ALT
levels,when compared to the levels of a similar enzyme, Albinism
aspartate aminotransferase (AST),may provide impor-
Definition
tant clues to the nature of the liver disease.

within a certain range of values,a ratio of 2:1 or greater Albinism is an inherited condition present at birth,
for AST:ALT might indicate that a patient suffers from characterized by a lack of pigment that normally gives
alcoholic liver disease. Other diagnostic data may be color to the skin,hair,and eyes. Many types of albinism
gleaned from ALT tests to indicate abnormal results. exist, all of which involve lack of pigment in varying
degrees. The condition,which is found in all races,may
Preparation be accompanied by eye problems and may lead to skin
cancerlater in life.
No special preparations are necessary for this test.

still not well understood.

beverages. of myoglobin, a breakdown product of muscle.

or other tissue.
muscles.
Cerebellum—The part of the brain involved in coor-
dination of movement, walking, and balance. Neuropathy—A condition affecting the nerves sup-
plying the arms and legs.

The symptoms of alcoholism can be broken down
into two major categories: symptoms of acute alcohol
Description use and symptoms of long-term alcohol use.
The effects of alcoholism are quite far-reaching.

Normal results
Aldosterone assay
Newborns have the highest normal aldolase levels
and adults the lowest.

--- Chunk 604 ---
Normal values will vary based on Definition
the laboratory and the method used.
This test measures the levels of aldosterone,a hor-
mone produced by the outer part (cortex) of the two
Abnormal results adrenal glands,organs which sit one on top of each of
the kidneys. Aldosterone regulates the amounts of sodi-
As noted,aldolase is elevated in skeletal muscle dis-
um and potassium in the blood. This helps maintain
eases,such as muscular dystrophies. Duchenne’s muscu-
water balance and blood volume,which,in turn,affects
lar dystrophy,the most common type of muscular dystro-

phy,will increase the aldolase level more than any other
disease.

--- Chunk 605 ---
Purpose
Nondisease conditions that affect the muscle,such
as injury,gangrene,or an infection,can also increase the Aldosterone measurement is useful in detecting a
aldolase level. Also,strenuous exercise can temporarily condition called aldosteronism, which is caused by
increase a person’s aldolase level. excess secretion of the hormone from the adrenal glands.
100 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
yassa
enoretsodlA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:41 PM Page 100
--- صفحة 115 ---
There are two types of aldosteronism:primary and sec-
ondary. Primary aldosteronism is most commonly caused
by an adrenal tumor,as in Conn’s syndrome. Idiopathic
(of unknown cause) hyperaldosteronismis another type
of primary aldosteronism.

--- Chunk 606 ---
Secondary aldosteronism is
more common and may occur with congestive heart fail-
ure, cirrhosis with fluid in the abdominal cavity
(ascites), certain kidney diseases, excess potassium,
sodium-depleted diet,and toxemia of pregnancy.
To differentiate primary aldosteronism from sec-
ondary aldosteronism,a plasma renin test should be per-
formed at the same time as the aldosterone assay. Renin,
an enzyme produced in the kidneys,is high in secondary
aldosteronism and low in primary aldosteronism. Risks
Risks for this test are minimal, but may include
slight bleeding from the blood-drawing site,faintingor
Description
feeling lightheaded after venipuncture, or hematoma
Aldosterone testing can be performed on a blood
(blood accumulating under the puncture site).

--- Chunk 607 ---
sample or on a 24-hour urine specimen. Several factors,
including diet,posture (upright or lying down),and time
Normal results
of day that the sample is obtained can cause aldosterone
Normal results are laboratory-specific and also vary
levels to fluctuate. Blood samples are affected by short-
with sodium intake,with time of day,source of specimen
term fluctuations. A urine specimen collected over an
(e.g.,peripheral vein,adrenal vein,24-hour urine),age,
entire 24-hour period lessens the effects of those inter-
sex,and posture.
fering factors and provides a more reliable aldosterone
measurement.

--- Chunk 608 ---

KEY TERMS
Aldosteronism—A condition in which the adrenal
glands secrete excessive levels of the hormone
aldosterone.
Renin—An enzyme produced in the kidneys that
controls the activation of the hormone angiotensin,
which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce
aldosterone.

Alkaline phosphatase is measured by combining the
person’s serum with specific substances with which alka-
line phosphatase is known to react. The end product of
this reaction is measured; and from that measurement,
Alkaline phosphatase test the amount of alkaline phosphatase in the person’s serum
is determined.

--- Chunk 641 ---

Each tissue—liver,bone,placenta,and intestine—

disease or a tumor. zymes react differently to heat, certain chemicals, and
other processes in the laboratory. Methods to measure
them separately are based on these differences.

--- Chunk 650 ---
Diagnosis
Diagnostic imaging
The diagnosis of ABPA is based on a combination of
Chest x rays and CT scans are used to check for the
the patient’s history and the results of blood tests,sputum
presence of fluid accumulation in the lungs and signs of
tests,skin tests,and diagnostic imaging. The doctor will
bronchiectasis.
be concerned to distinguish between ABPA and a wors-
ening of the patient’s asthma, cystic fibrosis, or other
Treatment
lung disorders. There are seven major criteria for a diag-
nosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis: ABPA is usually treated with prednisone (Meti-
•a history of asthma. corten) or other corticosteroids taken by mouth, and
with bronchodilators.
•an accumulation of fluid in the lung that is visible on a

condition known as allergy,and the offending substance

Richard Robinson
Like all allergic reactions,AR involves a special
set of cells in the immune system known as mast cells.
Mast cells, found in the lining of the nasal passages
and eyelids,display a special type of antibody,called
immunoglobulin type E (IgE),on their surface. Inside,
Allergic rhinitis
mast cells store reactive chemicals in small packets,
called granules. When the antibodies encounter aller-
Definition
gens,they trigger release of the granules,which spill

fever,is an inflammation of the nasal passages caused by blood vessels and nerve cells.

through special proteins called histamine receptors.

sels causes neighboring cells to become leaky,leading

afflictions. It affects between 10-20% of all people in

gic rhinitis.

Other potential causes of perennial allergic rhinitis
include the following:
•cigarette smoke
•perfume
•cosmetics
•cleansers
•copier chemicals
•industrial chemicals
•construction material gases
Symptoms
Inflammation of the nose, or rhinitis, is the major
symptom of AR. Inflammation causes itching,sneezing,
runny nose,redness,and tenderness.

--- Chunk 673 ---
Sinus swelling can
constrict the eustachian tube that connects the inner ear
to the throat,causing a congested feeling and “ear pop-
ping.”The drip of mucus from the sinuses down the back
of the throat, combined with increased sensitivity, can
also lead to throat irritation and redness. AR usually also
causes redness, itching, and watery eyes. Fatigue and
headacheare also common.
Diagnosis
Diagnosing seasonal AR is usually easy and can
often be done without a medical specialist. When symp-
toms appear in spring or summer and disappear with the
onset of cold weather, seasonal AR is almost certainly
the culprit.

--- Chunk 674 ---

allergy sufferer produce an unusually
large amount of IgE.

In a future exposure to the same substance,
the antibodies on the mast cells bind to the
allergens, and the cells release their histamine.
SECOND EXPOSURE
Histamine travels to receptor sites in the nasal
passages. When histamine molecules enter the
sites they trigger dilation of the blood vessels,
swelling, irritation, and increased production
of mucus.

--- Chunk 717 ---
Antihistamines
Antihistamine drugs block histamine molecules
from entering receptor sites, thus preventing or
reducing swelling, congestion and irritation.
Second and subsequent exposure to allergen.(Illustration by Hans & Cassady.)

--- Chunk 730 ---
Definition
Prevention Allergy tests indicate a person’s allergic sensitivity
to commonly encountered environmental substances.
Avoiding allergens is the best means of limiting
allergic reactions. For food allergies,there is no effective
treatment except avoidance. By determining the allergens Purpose
that are causing reactions,most people can learn to avoid
Allergy is a reaction of the immune system. Nor-
allergic reactions from food,drugs,and contact allergens
mally,the immune system responds to foreign microor-
such as poison ivy or latex. Airborne allergens are more
ganisms and particles,like pollen or dust,by producing
difficult to avoid,although keeping dust and animal dan-
specific proteins called antibodies that are capable of
der from collecting in the house may limit exposure.

--- صفحة 137 ---
gen,either through inhalation or ingestion. Positive reac-
tions from any of these tests may be used to narrow the
candidates for the actual allergen causing the allergy.
Identification of the allergenic substance may allow
the patient to avoid the substance and reduce allergic
reactions.

--- Chunk 737 ---
In addition, allergy testing may be done in
those with asthmathat is difficult to manage,eczema,or
skin rashesto determine if an allergy is causing the con-
dition or making it worse. Allergy tests may also be done
before allergen desensitization to ensure the safety of
more extensive exposure.
Skin testing is the most common type of allergy test.
There are two forms:percutaneous and intradermal. In
percutaneous or prick testing, allergen solutions are
placed on the skin, and the skin is then pricked with a
needle, allowing the allergen to enter the skin and
become exposed to mast cells. Scratch testing,in which
the skin is scratched instead of punctured, is used less Precautions
often.

--- Chunk 738 ---
Intradermal testing involves directly injecting While allergy tests are quite safe for most people,
allergen solutions into the skin. In both tests,a reddened, the possibility of a condition known as anaphylaxisdoes
swollen spot develops at the injection site for each sub- exist. Anaphylaxis is a potentially dangerous condition
stance to which the person is sensitive. Skin reactivity is that can result in difficulty breathing and a sharp drop in
seen for allergens regardless of whether they usually blood pressure. People with a known history of anaphy-
affect the skin. In other words,airborne and food aller- laxis should inform the testing clinician. Skin tests
gens cause skin reactions equally well. should never include a substance known to cause ana-
phylaxis in the person being tested.

KEY TERMS
Allergen—A substance that provokes an allergic
response.
Anaphylaxis—Increased sensitivity caused by pre-
vious exposure to an allergen that can result in
blood vessel dilation (swelling) and smooth mus-
cle contraction. Anaphylaxis can result in sharp
blood pressure drops and difficulty breathing.
Antibody—A specific protein produced by the
immune system in response to a specific foreign
protein or particle called an antigen.
Antigen—A foreign protein to which the body
reacts by making antibodies.
ies will bind to the solid medium and remain behind after Histamine—A chemical released by mast cells
a rinse.

radioactive dye. By locating radioactive spots on the found in the lining of the nasal passages and eye-
solid medium,the reactive allergens are discovered. lids, displays a type of antibody called immuno-

borne or food allergens. Inhalation testing is performed pates in the allergic response by releasing hista-
only after a patient’s lung capacity and response to the mine from intracellular granules.

Lack of redness or swelling on a skin test indicates
Skin testing does not usually require any aftercare. A no allergic response. In an inhalation test,the exhalation
generalized redness and swelling may occur in the test capacity should remain unchanged. In a food challenge,

testing. mm (1/4 inch) in diameter,indicates an allergic response.

--- صفحة 139 ---
This does not mean the substance actually causes the
patient’s symptoms,however,since he or she may have
no regular exposure to the allergen. In fact, the actual
allergen may not have been included in the test array.
Following allergen inhalation,reduction in exhala-
tion capacity of more than 20%, and for at least 10-20
minutes,indicates a positive reaction to the allergen.
Gastrointestinal symptoms within 24 hours follow-
ing the ingestion of a suspected food allergen indicates a
positive response.

Causes and symptoms
Alopecia •Male pattern baldness (androgenic alopecia) is consid-
ered normal in adult males. It is easily recognized by
Definition the distribution of hair loss over the top and front of the
head and by the healthy condition of the scalp.
Alopecia simply means hair loss (baldness).
•Alopecia areata is a hair loss condition of unknown
cause that can be patchy or extend to complete baldness.
Description
•Fungal infections of the scalp usually cause patchy hair

loss.

Patients should avoid missing any doses,and should not
Purpose take larger or more frequent doses to make up for
missed doses.
These drugs, called alpha blockers for short, are
used for two main purposes:to treat high blood pressure
(hypertension) and to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia Precautions
(BPH),a condition that affects men and is characterized

lightheadedness,heart palpitations,and fainting. Activ-

Altitude sickness occurs because the partial pressure
of oxygen decreases with altitude. (Partial pressure is a KEY TERMS
term applied to gases that is similar to the way the term
concentration is applied to liquid solutions.) For instance, Cerebral—Pertaining to the brain.
at 18,000 feet (5,486 m) the partial pressure of oxygen
Edema—Accumulation of excess fluid in the tis-
drops to one-half its value at sea level and,therefore,there
sues of the body.
is a substantially lower amount of oxygen available for the
individual to inhale. This is known as hypoxia. Further- Hypoxemia—Insufficient oxygenation of the blood.

--- Chunk 793 ---
more, since there is less oxygen to inhale, less oxygen Hypoxia—A deficiency in the amount of oxygen
reaches the blood. This is known as hypoxemia. These two required for effective ventilation.
conditions are the major factors that form the basis for all
Pulmonary—Pertaining to the lungs.
the medical problems associated with altitude sickness.

response is to breathe more rapidly (hyperventilate). This
is the body’s attempt to bring in more oxygen at a rapid

to afflict all types of individuals,regardless of their level
at higher altitudes is known as acclimatization, and it

--- صفحة 151 ---
Diagnosis
Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is complex, and
may require office visits to several different specialists
over several months before a diagnosis can be made.

--- Chunk 821 ---
While a confident provisional diagnosis may be made in
most cases after thorough testing,AD cannot be defini-
tively diagnosed until autopsy examination of the brain
for plaques and neurofibrillary tangles.
The diagnosis of AD begins with a thorough physi-
cal exam and complete medical history. Except in the
disease’s earliest stages, accurate history from family
members or caregivers is essential. Since there are both
prescription and over-the-counter drugs that can cause
the same mental changes as AD,a careful review of the
patient’s drug,medicine,and alcohol use is important.
AD-like symptoms can also be provoked by other med-
ical conditions,including tumors,infection,and demen-
tia caused by mild strokes (multi-infarct dementia).

--- Chunk 822 ---
Treatment
These possibilities must be ruled out as well through
appropriate blood and urine tests,brain magnetic reso- Alzheimer’s disease is presently incurable,so there-
nance imaging(MRI),positron emission tomography fore the mainstay of treatment for a person with AD is
(PET) or single photon emission computed tomography good nursing care,providing both physical and emotion-
(SPECT) scans, tests of the brain’s electrical activity al support for a person who is gradually able to do less
(electroencephalographs or EEGs),or other tests. Several and less for himself, and whose behavior is becoming
types of oral and written tests are used to aid in the AD more and more erratic.

--- Chunk 823 ---

Definition two eyes are looking in two different directions at the
same time. The brain is sent two different images and

Amebiasis is an infectious disease caused by a para-
looking ameba called Entamoeba dispar. During their
sitic one-celled microorganism (protozoan) called Enta-
life cycles,the amebas exist in two very different forms:
moeba histolytica. Persons with amebiasis may experi-

Amino acid disorders Precautions
screening
Both blood and urine tests are simple tests that can
be done in a doctor’s office or clinic. These tests can be
Definition
done on even the youngest patients.
Amino acid disorder screening checks for inherited
disorders in amino acid metabolism.

--- Chunk 897 ---

monly done on newborns. Two tests are available, one
Two types of amino acid screening tests are used
using a blood sample and the other a urine sample.
together to diagnose amino acid disorders.

“Aminoglycosides & Spectinomycin.”In Basic and Clini-
cal Pharmacology.7th ed. Ed. Bertram G. Katzung. Stam- Amnesia refers to the loss of memory. Memory loss
ford:Appleton & Lange,1998.

--- Chunk 916 ---
may result from two-sided (bilateral) damage to parts of
GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 151
Amnesia
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 151
--- صفحة 166 ---
tion,drug and alcohol abuse,or reduced blood flow to
the brain (vascular insufficiency). In Wernicke-Korsakoff
syndrome,for example,damage to the memory centers
of the brain results from the use of alcohol or malnutri-
tion. Infections that damage brain tissue, including
encephalitisand herpes,can also cause amnesia. If the
amnesia is thought to be of psychological origin, it is
termed psychogenic.
There are at least three general types of amnesia:
•Anterograde. This form of amnesia follows brain trau-
ma and is characterized by the inability to remember
new information.

--- Chunk 917 ---
Recent experiences and short-term
memory disappear,but victims can recall events prior
to the trauma with clarity.
•Retrograde. In some ways,this form of amnesia is the
opposite of anterograde amnesia:the victim can recall
events that occurred after a trauma,but cannot remem-
ber previously familiar information or the events pre-
ceding the trauma.
•Transient global amnesia. This type of amnesia has no
consistently identifiable cause, but researchers have
suggested that migraines or transient ischemic attacks
may be the trigger.

--- Chunk 918 ---
(A transient ischemic attack,
sometimes called “a small stroke,” occurs when a
the brain vital for memory storage,processing,or recall blockage in an artery temporarily blocks off blood sup-
(the limbic system, including the hippocampus in the ply to part of the brain.) A victim experiences sudden
medial temporal lobe). confusion and forgetfulness. Attacks can be as brief as
30-60 minutes or can last up to 24 hours. In severe
Description attacks, a person is completely disoriented and may
experience retrograde amnesia that extends back sever-
Amnesia can be a symptom of several neurodegen-
al years.

--- Chunk 919 ---
While very frightening for the patient, tran-
erative diseases; however,people whose primary symp-
sient global amnesia generally has an excellent progno-
tom is memory loss (amnesiacs),typically remain lucid
sis for recovery.
and retain their sense of self. They may even be aware
that they suffer from a memory disorder.
Diagnosis
People who experience amnesia have been instrumen-
tal in helping brain researchers determine how the brain In diagnosing amnesia and its cause,doctors look at
processes memory. Until the early 1970s, researchers several factors. During a physical examination,the doc-
viewed memory as a single entity.

--- Chunk 920 ---

ences,motor skills,past events,and previous conditioning medication history, and checks the patient’s general
were grouped together in one system that relied on a spe- health. Psychological exams may be ordered to deter-
cific area of the brain. mine the extent of amnesia and the memory system
affected. The doctor may also order imaging tests such as
If all memory were stored in the same way,it would
magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) to reveal whether
be reasonable to deduce that damage to the specific brain
the brain has been damaged,and blood work to exclude
area would cause complete memory loss. However,stud-
treatable metabolic causes or chemical imbalances.
ies of amnesiacs counter that theory.

--- Chunk 921 ---
Such research
demonstrates that the brain has multiple systems for pro-
cessing,storing,and drawing on memory. Treatment

Prevention
Amnesia is only preventable in so far as brain injury
can be prevented or minimized. Common sense approach-
es include wearing a helmet when bicycling or participat-
Amniocentesis
ing in potentially dangerous sports,using automobile seat
belts,and avoiding excessive alcohol or drug use. Brain
Definition
infections should be treated swiftly and aggressively to
minimize the damage due to swelling.

--- Chunk 952 ---
Figure A:After the surgeon creates two flaps of skin and tissue,the muscle is cut and the main artery and
veins of the femur bone are exposed.Figure B:The surgeon severs the main artery and veins.New connections are formed
between them,restoring blood circulation.The sciatic nerve is then pulled down,clamped and tied,and severed.Figure C:
The surgeon saws through the exposed femur bone.Figure D:The muscles are closed and sutured over the bone.The
remaining skin flaps are then sutured together,creating a stump.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)

nervous system are affected most often. Other common

rarediseases.org>. Causes
OTHER The symptoms of ALS are caused by the death of
Mayo Clinic Online.5 March 1998. <http://www.mayohealth.org>. motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain. Normally,these
neurons convey electrical messages from the brain to the
Maureen Haggerty muscles to stimulate movement in the arms,legs,trunk,
neck,and head. As motor neurons die,the muscles they
enervate cannot be moved as effectively, and weakness
results. In addition, lack of stimulation leads to muscle
wasting,or loss of bulk. Involvement of the upper motor
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis neurons causes spasms and increased tone in the limbs,and
abnormal reflexes.

--- Chunk 979 ---
Involvement of the lower motor neurons
Definition causes muscle wasting and twitching (fasciculations).

caused by the inheritance of one or more faulty genes.
About 15% of families with this type of ALS have muta-

NORMAL SPINAL NEURON DISEASED SPINAL NEURON
Normal nerve fiber Affected nerve fiber
Normal skeletal muscle Wasted skeletal muscle
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is caused by the degeneration and death of motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain.

--- Chunk 984 ---
These neurons convey electrical messages from the brain to the muscles to stimulate movement in the arms,legs,trunk,
neck,and head.As motor neurons degenerate,the muscles are weakened and cannot move as effectively,leading to muscle
wasting.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)
--- صفحة 179 ---
rapid in the legs among people with familial ALS and in
the arms among those with sporadic ALS. Leg weakness KEY TERMS
may first become apparent by an increased frequency of
stumbling on uneven pavement,or an unexplained diffi- Aspiration—Inhalation of food or liquids into the
culty climbing stairs. Arm weakness may lead to difficul- lungs.
ty grasping and holding a cup, for instance, or loss of
Bulbar muscles—Muscles of the mouth and throat
dexterity in the fingers.

--- Chunk 985 ---
responsible for speech and swallowing.
Less often,the earliest sign of ALS is weakness in
Fasciculations—Involuntary twitching of muscles.

throat that control chewing,swallowing,and speaking. A Motor neuron—A nerve cell that controls a mus-
person with bulbar weakness may become hoarse or tired cle.
after speaking at length,or speech may become slurred. Riluzole (Rilutek)—The first drug approved in the

ALS are muscle wasting and persistent twitching (fascic- Voluntary muscle—A muscle under conscious

An anaerobic infection is an infection caused by
bacteria (called anaerobes) which cannot grow in the
presence of oxygen. Anaerobic bacteria can infect deep Causes and symptoms
wounds,deep tissues,and internal organs where there is

little oxygen.

•Stage II anal cancer has spread beyond the top layer of
anal tissue and is larger than 1 inch in diameter,but has KEY TERMS
not spread to nearby organs or lymph nodes.
•Stage IIIA anal cancer has spread to the lymph nodes Biopsy—A procedure in which a small piece of
around the rectum or to nearby organs such as the vagi- body tissue is removed and examined under a
na or bladder. microscope for cancer.
•Stage IIIB anal cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the Chemotherapy—A cancer treatment in which
mid-abdomen or groin, or to nearby organs and the drugs delivered into the blood stream kill cancer
lymph nodes around the rectum.

increase the risk of certain cancers.

--- Chunk 1028 ---
Warts that appear inside the anal
canal will almost always be treated with cauterization or
surgical removal. Surgical removal,also known as exci-
sion,has the highest success rates and lowest recurrence
rates. Indeed,studies have shown that initial cure rates
Anal warts range from 63–91%.

Acute pain—Pain that is usually temporary and
results from something specific, such as a surgery, Interactions
an injury, or an infection.

gesic. See specific references.
Chronic pain—Pain that lasts more than three
months and threatens to disrupt daily life.

Inflammation—Pain, redness, swelling, and heat
that usually develop in response to injury or illness.
Osteoarthritis—Joint pain resulting from damage
to the cartilage.

Anaphylaxis is a type of allergic reaction,in which •papain from meat tenderizers
the immune system responds to otherwise harmless sub- •vaccines,including flu and measlesvaccines
stances from the environment. Unlike other allergic
•penicillin

Reaction may

•gamma globulin

•hormones (ACTH,thyroid-stimulating hormone)

•latex,from exam gloves or condoms,for example
Causes
Exposure to cold or exercisecan trigger anaphylaxis
Like the majority of other allergic reactions,anaphy-
in some individuals.
laxis is caused by the release of histamine and other
chemicals from mast cells.

--- Chunk 1067 ---
Mast cells are a type of white
Symptoms
blood cell and they are found in large numbers in the tis-
sues that regulate exchange with the environment: the Symptoms may include:
airways,digestive system,and skin.
•urticaria (hives)
On their surfaces, mast cells display antibodies
•swelling and irritation of the tongue or mouth
called IgE (immunoglobulin type E). These antibodies
are designed to detect environmental substances to •swelling of the sinuses
which the immune system is sensitive. Substances from •difficulty breathing
a genuinely threatening source, such as bacteria or
•wheezing
viruses,are called antigens. A substance that most peo-
ple tolerate well, but to which others have an allergic •cramping,vomiting,or diarrhea
response, is called an allergen.

--- Chunk 1068 ---
When IgE antibodies •anxiety or confusion
bind with allergens,they cause the mast cell to release
•strong,very rapid heartbeat (palpitations)
histamine and other chemicals, which spill out onto
neighboring cells. •loss of consciousness
The interaction of these chemicals with receptors on Not all symptoms may be present.
the surface of blood vessels causes the vessels to leak
fluid into surrounding tissues,causing fluid accumula-
Diagnosis
tion,redness,and swelling. On the smooth muscle cells
of the airways and digestive system,they cause constric- Anaphylaxis is diagnosed based on the rapid devel-
tion. On nerve endings, they increase sensitivity and opment of symptoms in response to a suspect allergen.
cause itching.

allergens. Skin testing may be done for less severe ana-
extreme hypersensivity to the allergen and its usually
phylactic reactions.

KEY TERMS Anemias
Definition
ACTH—Adrenocorticotropic hormone, a hor-
mone normally produced by the pituitary gland, Anemia is a condition characterized by abnormally
sometimes taken as a treatment for arthritis and low levels of healthy red blood cells or hemoglobin (the
other disorders. component of red blood cells that delivers oxygen to tis-
sues throughout the body).
Antibody—An immune system protein which
binds to a substance from the environment.
Description
NSAIDs—Non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs,
including aspirin and ibuprofen. The tissues of the human body need a regular supply
of oxygen to stay healthy.

--- Chunk 1072 ---
Red blood cells,which contain
Tracheostomy tube—A tube which is inserted into
hemoglobin that allows them to deliver oxygen throughout
an incision in the trachea (tracheostomy) to relieve
the body,live for only about 120 days. When they die,the
upper airway obstruction.
iron they contain is returned to the bone marrow and used
to create new red blood cells. Anemia develops when
heavy bleeding causes significant iron loss or when some-
thing happens to slow down the production of red blood

cells or to increase the rate at which they are destroyed.

tion of the likely severity of reaction: the faster symp- Types of anemia

Diagnosis
Personal and family health history may suggest the
presence of certain types of anemia. Laboratory tests that
measure the percentage of red blood cells or the amount
of hemoglobin in the blood are used to confirm diagnosis
and determine which type of anemia is responsible for a
patient’s symptoms. X rays and examinations of bone

marrow may be used to identify the source of bleeding.
mia are especially susceptible to infection. Treatment for
aplastic anemia may involve blood transfusions and bone
Treatment marrow transplant to replace malfunctioning cells with
healthy ones.

Definition
concerns about transmitting disease-causing genes to
their children.

Anesthetics: How They Work
Type Name(s) Administered Affect
General Halothane, Enflurane Isoflurane, Intravenously, Inhalation Produces total unconsciousness affecting the
Ketamine, Nitrous Oxide, Thiopental entire body
Regional Mepivacaine, Chloroprocaine, Lidocaine Intravenously Temporarily interrupts transmission of nerve impuls-
es (temperature, touch, pain) and motor functions in
a large area to be treated; does not produce uncon-
sciousness
Local Procaine, Lidocaine, Tetracaine, Bupivacaine Intravenously Temporarily blocks transmission of nerve impulses
and motor functions in a specific area; does not pro-
duce unconsciousness
Topical Benzocaine, Lidocaine Dibucaine, Demal (Sprays, Drope, Ointments, Temporarily blocks nerve endings in skin and
Pramoxine, Butamben, Tetracaine Creams, Gels) mucous membranes; does not produce uncon-
sciousness

Dental anesthetics (non-injectable)
KEY TERMS
Dental anesthetics should not be used if certain
kinds of infections are present. Check package directions
Canker sore—A painful sore inside the mouth.
or check with a dentist or medical doctor if uncertain.

Aneurysm—A weakening in the muscular walls of
a part of the artery which causes the damaged sec-
tion to enlarge or sag, giving it a balloon-like
appearance.
Angina
Aorta—The main blood vessel that leads away
from the heart and the body’s largest artery. The
Definition
aorta carries blood from the heart through the
chest and abdomen, providing major branches to Angina is pain,“discomfort,”or pressure localized
all of the organs in the body.

--- Chunk 1154 ---

Arteriosclerosis—Hardening of the arteries that
times characterized by a feeling of choking,suffocation,
occurs as part of the aging process.
or crushing heaviness. This condition is also called angi-
Artery—A blood vessel that carries blood from the na pectoris.
heart to the body’s tissues.
Atherosclerosis—A form of arteriosclerosis in
Description
which cholesterol-containing fatty deposits accu-
mulate in the inner most walls of the heart’s arteries. Often described as a muscle spasm and choking sen-
sation, the term “angina” is used primarily to describe
Thoracic—Relating to the chest.
chest (thoracic) pain originating from insufficient oxygen
to the heart muscle.

--- Chunk 1155 ---

--- Chunk 1170 ---
Prevention
Angiography
In most cases,the best prevention involves changing
one’s habits to avoid bringing on attacks of angina. If
Definition
blood pressure medication has been prescribed,compli-
ance is a necessity and should be a priority as well. Many Angiography is the x-ray study of the blood vessels.
healthcare professionals—including physicians, dieti- An angiogram uses a radiopaque substance, or dye, to
196 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
yhpargoignA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 196
--- صفحة 211 ---
make the blood vessels visible under x ray. Arteriography is
a type of angiography that involves the study of the arteries.

--- Chunk 1171 ---
Purpose
Angiography is used to detect abnormalities or
blockages in the blood vessels (called occlusions)
throughout the circulatory system and in some organs.
The procedure is commonly used to identify atheroscle-
rosis; to diagnose heart disease; to evaluate kidney func-
tion and detect kidney cysts or tumors; to detect an
aneurysm (an abnormal bulge of an artery that can rup-
ture leading to hemorrhage),tumor,blood clot,or arteri-
ovenous malformations(abnormals tangles of arteries
and veins) in the brain; and to diagnose problems with
the retina of the eye. It is also used to give surgeons an
accurate “map”of the heart prior to open-heart surgery,
or of the brain prior to neurosurgery.

--- Chunk 1172 ---
Precautions
Patients with kidney disease or injury may suffer
further kidney damage from the contrast mediums used
for angiography. Patients who have blood clotting prob-
study. A fluoroscopic screen that displays a view of the
lems,have a known allergy to contrast mediums,or are
patient’s vascular system is used to pilot the wire to the
allergic to iodine,a component of some contrast medi-
correct location. Once it is in position, the needle is
ums,may also not be suitable candidates for an angiogra-
removed and a catheter is slid over the length of the
phy procedure. Because x rays carry risks of ionizing
guide wire until it to reaches the area of study.

the condition puts a burden on the heart and the arteries, patients may have to take medicine for the rest of their
which can lead to permanent damage over time. If lives. Furthermore,medicine alone may not be enough.
untreated,high blood pressure increases the risk of heart Patients with high blood pressure may also need to avoid
attacks,heart failure,stroke,or kidney failure. certain foods,such as salty snacks,and keep their weight
under control.

ACE plays an important role in the renin/aldosterone

--- صفحة 220 ---
Children are the most frequent victims of dog bites,with
KEY TERMS 5-9 year-old boys having the highest incidence. Men are
more often bitten by dogs than are women (3:1),whereas
Sarcoidosis—Sarcoidosis is a rare disease of women are more often bitten by cats (3:1).

--- Chunk 1226 ---
unknown cause in which inflammation occurs in Dog bites make up 80-85% of all reported incidents.
lymph nodes and other tissues throughout the Cats account for about 10% of reported bites,and other
body, usually the lungs, skin, liver, and eyes. animals (including rodents, rabbits, horses, raccoons,
bats, skunks, and monkeys) make up the remaining 5-
10%. Cat bites become infected more frequently than
dog bites. A dog’s mouth is rich in bacteria,but only 15-
Abnormal results 20% of dog bites become infected. In contrast,approxi-
mately 30-50% of cat bites become infected.
Serum ACE levels are elevated in approximately 80-
90% of patients with active sarcoidosis.

--- Chunk 1227 ---

206 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
snoitcefni
etib
laminA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 206
--- صفحة 221 ---
and bones,causing inflammation of the bone and bone
marrow or septic arthritis.
Cat-scratch disease is caused by Bartonella hense-
lae, a bacterium that is carried in cat saliva; infection
may be transmitted by a bite or scratch. Approximately
22,000 cases are reported each year in the United States;
worldwide, nine out of every 100,000 individuals
become infected. More than 80% of reported cases occur
in persons under the age of 21. The disease is not nor-
mally severe in individuals with healthy immune sys-
tems.

--- Chunk 1233 ---
Symptoms may become serious, however, in
immunocompromised individuals, such as those with
acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) or those
undergoing chemotherapy. Common symptoms include
an inflamed sore in the area of the bite or scratch,
swollen lymph nodes,fever,fatigue,and rash.
Rabies is caused by a virus that is transmitted through
the bite of an animal that is already infected. More than
90% of animal rabies cases occur in wild animals such as
skunks,bats,and raccoons,with domestic animals such as
dogs and cats accounting for less than 10%. The World
Health Organization (WHO) estimates that between
35,000 and 50,000 individuals worldwide die each year as
a result of rabies.

--- Chunk 1234 ---
The highest incidence of rabies occurs in
Asia where,in 1997,over 33,000 deaths were noted,most
occurring in India. Rabies is nowadays rare in the U.S. due
to good animal control practice. The delay of onset is usu-
ally weeks to months after being bitten. Early symptoms
of rabies include fever,headache,and flu-like symptoms.
These progress to anxiety, hallucinations, muscle
spasms,partial paralysis,fear of water (hydrophobia),and
other neurological symptoms as the virus spreads to the
central nervous system. Medical treatment must be sought
soon after exposure because deathinvariably follows once
the infection becomes established.
infected as thoroughly as possible.

--- Chunk 1235 ---
Bites to the head and

checked. An x ray may be ordered to assess bone damage If infection occurs, antibiotics are prescribed.
and to check for foreign objects in the wound. Wound Antibiotics may also be used for infection prevention.

There is no cure for AS,and the course of the disease
AS is seen most commonly in males 30 years old
is unpredictable. Generally,AS progresses for about 10
and older. Initial symptoms are uncommon after the age
years and then its progression levels off. Most patients
of 30, although the diagnosis may not be established
can lead normal lives with treatment to control symptoms.
until after that age. The incidence of AS in Afro-Ameri-
cans is about 25% of the incidence in Caucasians.
Prevention
Diagnosis There is no known way to prevent AS.

Proctitisis an inflammation of the internal mucosal
lining of the rectum. Ulcers of the lining may form and
Anorectal abscess see Anorectal disorders
develop into ulcerative colitis. There are many causes of
proctitis, including the sexually transmitted diseases
chlamydia and herpes simplex infections.

Anorexia is a disorder that results from the interac-

by unrealistic fear of weight gain, self-starvation, and factors. While the precise cause of the disease is not

Purpose
This test may be ordered for the evaluation of peri-
anal or anal pain,hemorrhoids,rectal prolapse,digital laxative,enema,or other preparation that may help with
rectal examinationthat shows a mass,perianal abscess the evacuation.
and condyloma (a wart-like growth). An anascopy may
be performed to check for abnormal openings between
Aftercare
the anus and the skin, or anal fissures.

used to diagnose rectal cancer. If a biopsy is needed during an anoscopy,there may
be slight anal bleeding for less than two days following
Precautions the procedure. The patient may be instructed to sit in a
bathtub of warm water for 10 to 15 minutes,three times a

day,to help decrease the pain and swelling.

constricted or narrowed anal canal.
A simple anoscopy procedure offers minimal risks.
There is a limited risk of bleeding and mild pain is a
Description
biopsy is performed.
Anoscopy views the anus and anal canal by using an
anoscope.

Treatment
Cessation of smokingis the first step. Many smok-
ers who quit discover new tastes so enthusiastically that
they immediately gain weight. Attention to reducing
Anosmia
exposure to other nasal irritants and treatment of respira-
Definition tory allergiesor chronic upper respiratory infections will
be beneficial. Corticosteroidsare particularly helpful.
The term anosmia means lack of the sense of smell.
It may also refer to a decreased sense of smell. Ageusia,a
Alternative treatment
companion word, refers to a lack of taste sensation.

Causes and symptoms
Anoxia and hypoxia can be caused by any number of
disease states of the blood,lungs,heart and circulation
Anoxia
including heart attack,severe asthma,or emphysema.
It can also result from smoke or carbon monoxide inhala-
Definition

oxygen supply to an organ or a tissue. mountain climbing or travel in an insufficiently pressur-
ized airplane.

KEY TERMS Antenatal testing
Definition
Acid indigestion—Indigestion that results from too
much acid in the stomach. Antenatal testing includes any diagnostic procedures
performed before the birth of a baby.
Chronic—A word used to describe a long-lasting
condition. Chronic conditions often develop grad-
ually and involve slow changes.

--- Chunk 1303 ---
Purpose
Heartburn—A burning sensation, usually in the These tests and exams are essential for protecting
center of the chest, near the breastbone. the health of a pregnant woman and her developing child.
Indigestion—A feeling of discomfort or illness that
results from the inability to properly digest food.
Precautions
Inflamed bowel—Irritation of the intestinal tract.
Some tests,such as amniocentisis,carry a small risk
Inflammation—Pain, redness, swelling, and heat of a miscarriageor other complications that could harm
that usually develop in response to injury or illness. the mother or baby.

--- Chunk 1304 ---
Pregnancy safety categories—A system for report-
ing the known safety issues of drugs for use during Description
pregnancy, The ratings range from A, proven safe
Women who become pregnant undergo a wide vari-
by well controlled studies, to X, proven harmful.
ety of tests throughout the nine months before delivery.
In the early stages,physicians order blood tests to screen
for possible disorders or infections, such as human
immunodeficiencyvirus (HIV),which can pass from the
tion of antacids through breast milk causes problems for
mother to the fetus. Later,the focus shifts to checking on
nursing babies whose mothers use antacids occasionally.
fetal well-being with a variety of technological tools
such as ultrasound scans.

--- Chunk 1305 ---

listed below.

rhea, thirst, stomach cramps, and whitish or speckled gestational diabetes,make sure she is immune to rubel-

unless they do not go away or they interfere with normal like HIV, hepatitis, chlamydia or syphilis.

activities. also usually do pelvic examto screen for cervical can-

as a sonogram. The procedure takes a few minutes,is pain-
less and usually is covered by health insurance.
Samuel Uretsky,PharmD

Description
Melissa Knopper
Technology
The NST and CST use a technique called electronic
fetal monitoringto evaluate the heartbeat of the fetus.
The biophysical profile is an ultrasound examination.
Antepartum testing
NST
Definition
The NST is usually the first antepartum test used to
Antepartum testing consists of a variety of tests per-
verify fetal well-being.

--- Chunk 1319 ---
It is based on the principle that
formed late in pregnancyto verify fetal well-being,as
when the fetus moves,its heartbeat normally speeds up.
judged by the baby’s heart rate and other characteristics.
The NST assesses fetal health through monitoring accel-
Antepartum tests include the nonstress test (NST),bio-
erations of the heart rate in response to the baby’s own
physical profile,and contraction stress test(CST).
movements,i.e.,in the absence of stress.
The mother lays down or sits,and an electronic fetal

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 223
Anthrax
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 223
--- صفحة 238 ---
animal hides (farmers, butchers, and veterinarians) or
sort wool. It is also possible to become infected with
anthrax by eating meat from contaminated animals.
There are no reports of the disease spreading from one
person to another.
Symptoms vary depending on how the disease was
contracted,but the symptoms usually appear within one
week of exposure.

--- Chunk 1333 ---
Cutaneous anthrax
In humans,anthrax usually occurs when the bacteria
enter a cut or abrasion,causing a skin (cutaneous) infec-
tion at the site. Cutaneous anthrax, as this infection is
called, is the mildest form of the disease. At first, the
bacteria cause an itchy, raised area like an insect bite.
Within one to two days,inflammation occurs around the
raised area,and a blister forms around an area of dying
The largest outbreak ever recorded in the United
tissue that becomes black in the center. Other symptoms

inated shipment from Pakistan.

anti-acne drug. These drugs usually come with written
Antiacne drugs directions for patients and should be used only as direct-

Definition medicine should check with a physician or pharmacist.
