--- صفحة 247 ---
Purpose
KEY TERMS
Normally,the heart beats at a steady,even pace.

--- Chunk 1387 ---
The
pace is controlled by electrical signals that begin in one part
Anxiety—Worry or tension in response to real or
of the heart and quickly spread through the whole heart. If
imagined stress, danger, or dreaded situations.
something goes wrong with this control system,the result
Physical reactions, such as fast pulse, sweating,
may be an irregular heartbeat, or an arrhythmia. Antiar-
trembling, fatigue, and weakness may accompany
rhythmic drugs correct irregular heartbeats,restoring the
anxiety.
normal rhythm. If the heart is beating too fast,these drugs
Epilepsy—A brain disorder with symptoms that will slow it down. By correcting these problems,antiar-
include seizures. rhythmic drugs help the heart work more efficiently.

--- Chunk 1388 ---
Panic disorder—An disorder in which people have
sudden and intense attacks of anxiety in certain Description
situations. Symptoms such as shortness of breath,

no fetal risk, but no human studies; or adverse SR), and quinidine (Cardioquin, Duraquin, Quinidex,
effects in animals, but not in well-controlled and other brands). Do not confuse quinidine with qui-
human studies. nine,which is a related medicine with different uses,such
as relieving leg cramps.
Pregnancy category C—No adequate human or
animal studies; or adverse fetal effects in animal
studies, but no available human data.
Recommended dosage
Seizure—A sudden attack, spasm, or convulsion.
The recommended dosage depends on the type of
antiarrhythmic drug and other factors. Doses may be dif-
ferent for different patients.

KEY TERMS
Anxiety—Worry or tension in response to real or Inflammation—Pain, redness, swelling, and heat
imagined stress, danger, or dreaded situations. that usually develop in response to injury or illness.
Physical reactions, such as fast pulse, sweating,
Myasthenia gravis—A chronic disease with symp-
trembling, fatigue, and weakness may accompany
toms that include muscle weakness and sometimes
anxiety.
paralysis.
Arrhythmia—Abnormal heart rhythm.
Palpitation—Rapid, forceful, throbbing, or fluttering
Asthma—A disease in which the air passages of the heartbeat.
lungs become inflamed and narrowed.

--- Chunk 1399 ---

Emphysema—A lung disease in which breathing
in men that contributes to the production of semen.
becomes difficult.
Psoriasis—A skin disease in which people have
Glaucoma—A condition in which pressure in the
itchy, scaly, red patches on the skin.
eye is abnormally high. If not treated, glaucoma
may lead to blindness. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)—A chronic
disease that affects the skin, joints, and certain
Hallucination—A false or distorted perception of
internal organs.
objects, sounds, or events that seems real. Hallucina-
tions usually result from drugs or mental disorders.

longed exposure to high heat. Heat stroke interferes
uncontrollable movements.

Antibiotic-associated colitis is caused by toxins pro-

Check with a physician or pharmacist before com-

begun.

--- Chunk 1417 ---
The early signs and symptoms of this disease
include lower abdominal cramps, an increased need to
pass stool,and watery diarrhea. As the disease progress-
es, the patient may experience a general ill feeling,
Antibiotic-associated colitis

ceeds to pseudomembranous enterocolitis, the patient

ciated enterocolitis is to repopulate the intestinal envi-

fluids,the prognosis is generally excellent. One or more
relapses can occur. Very severe colitis can cause a tear
(perforation) in the wall of the large intestine that would Description
require major surgery. Perforation of the intestine can

--- صفحة 255 ---
penicillins are effective against a wider range of bacteria.
These generally include coverage for Pseudomonas
aeruginaosaand may provide the penicillin in combina-
tion with a penicillinase inhibitor.
CEPHALOSPORINS.

--- Chunk 1432 ---
Cephalosporinsand the closely
related cephamycins and carbapenems, like the pen-
cillins,contain a beta-lactam chemical structure. Conse-
quently,there are patterns of cross-resistance and cross-
allergenicity among the drugs in these classes. The
“cepha” drugs are among the most diverse classes of
antibiotics,and are themselves subgrouped into 1st,2nd
and 3rd generations. Each generation has a broader spec-
trum of activity than the one before. In addition,cefox-
itin, a cephamycin, is highly active against anaerobic
bacteria,which offers utility in treatment of abdominal
infections. The 3rd generation drugs,cefotaxime,cefti-
zoxime, ceftriaxone and others, cross the blood-brain
barrier and may be used to treat meningitis and
encephalitis.

--- Chunk 1433 ---
Cephalopsorins are the usually preferred
agents for surgical prophylaxis.
FLUROQUINOLONES. The fluroquinolones are syn-
thetic antibacterial agents,and not derived from bacteria.
They are included here because they can be readily inter-
tions; the lincosamindes,clindamycin and lincomycin,
changed with traditional antibiotics. An earlier,related
which are highly active against anaerobic pathogens.
class of antibacterial agents, the quinolones, were not

in specific infections.

the older group,are broad-spectrum bacteriocidal drugs
that are chemically unrelated to the penicillins or the Recommended dosage
cephaloprosins.

Different antibiotics destroy bacteria in different ways.Some short-circuit the processes by which bacteria receive energy.
Others disturb the structure of the bacterial cell wall,as shown in the illustration above.

--- Chunk 1441 ---
Still others interfere with the produc-
tion of essential proteins.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)

KEY TERMS
Ophthalmic antibiotics are applied to the eye, or
under the eyelid,to treat eye infections caused by bacteria.
Bacteria—Tiny, one-celled forms of life that cause
many diseases and infections.

Precautions
Many public health experts are concerned about
antibiotic resistance, a problem that can develop when
Antibiotics, topical
antibiotics are overused. Over time,bacteria develop new
defenses against antibiotics that once were effective
Definition
against them.

--- Chunk 1451 ---
Because bacteria reproduce so quickly,
Topical antibioticsare medicines applied to the skin these defenses can be rapidly passed on through genera-
to kill bacteria. tions of bacteria until almost all are immune to the

PERIODICALS
act by interfering with cell growth. Since cancerous cells
Farley,Dixie. “Help for Cuts,Scrapes and Burns.”FDA Con-
grow more rapidly than other cells,the drugs target those
sumer(May 1996):12.
cells which are in the process of reproducing themselves.

--- Chunk 1458 ---
As a result, antineoplastic drugs will commonly affect
Nancy Ross-Flanigan
not only the cancerous cells,but others cells that com-
monly reproduce quickly,including hair follicles,ovaries
Antibody screening see Blood typing and
and testis,and the blood-forming organs.
crossmatching
Newer approaches to antineoplastic drug therapy
have taken different approaches,including angigenesis—
the inhibition of formation of blood vessels feeding the
tumor and contributing to tumor growth. Although these
approaches hold promise,they are not yet in common use.
Anticancer drugs
Antineoplastic drugs may be divided into two class-
Definition es:cycle specific and non-cycle specific.

--- Chunk 1459 ---
Cycle specific
drugs act only at specific points of the cell’s duplication
Anticancer,or antineoplastic,drugs are used to treat
cycle,such as anaphase or metaphase,while non-cycle
malignancies,cancerous growths. Drug therapy may be
specific drugs may act at any point in the cell cycle. In
used alone,or in combination with other treatments such
order to gain maximum effect,antineoplastic drugs are
as surgery or radiation therapy.
commonly used in combinations.
Purpose
Precautions
Anticancer drugs are used to control the growth of
cancerous cells.

•immune system disease immediately be consulted if any of the following occur:
•cataractsor other eye problems •black,tarry,or bloody stools
•high cholesterol •blood in the urine
•diarrhea
Other precautions
•fever or chills

•cough or hoarseness
cautions. Patients should be given advice on the effects of
sun exposure and the use of alcohol and painrelievers.

antiplatelet drugs
•Inhibitors of thrombin. Thrombin inhibitors interfere
with blood clotting by blocking the activity of throm-
bin. They include heparin,lepirudin (Refludan).
•Antiplatelet drugs. Antiplatelet drugs interact with
Anticoagulant and
platelets, which is a type of blood cell, to block
antiplatelet drugs platelets from aggregating into harmful clots. They
include:aspirin,ticlopidine (Ticlid),clopidogrel (Plav-
Definition
ix),tirofiban (Aggrastat),and eptifibatide (Integrilin).
Anticoagulants are drugs used to prevent clot forma-
tion or to prevent a clot that has formed from enlarging.

--- Chunk 1515 ---
Tricyclic compounds, identified by their chemical
Nancy Ross-Flanigan
structure containing three carbon rings,are an older class
of antidepressants. Although generally effective, they
have a high incidence of anticholinergic effects,notably
dry mouth and dry eyes, which can cause discomfort.
They also cause cardiac arrythmias. Because tricyclics
Antidepressant drugs
act on both serotonin and norepinephrine,they may have
Definition some value in treatment of patients who fail to respond to
SSRIs. Drugs in this class are often available at low
Antidepressant drugs are medicines that relieve
prices, which may be significant when cost is a major
symptoms of depressive disorders.
factor in treatment. They have also been found useful in
control of some neurologic painsyndromes.

tionand the extent of the anticholinergic effects.
ods of extreme excitation). The formal diagnosis requires

Antidepressant Drugs
Brand Name (Generic Name) Possible Common Side Effects Include:
Desyrel (trazodone hydrochloride) Allergic skin reactions, blurred vision, decreased appetite, fluid retention, headache
Effexor (venlafaxine hydrochloride) Diarrhea, dizziness, gas, headache, insommia, rash, vomiting
Elavil (amitriptyline hydrochloride) Constipation, idzziness, high blood pressure, fever, nausea, rash, weight gain or loss
Nardil (phenelzine sulfate) Dry mouth, fatigue, headache, muscle spasms, tremors
Norpramin (desipramine hydrochloride) Blurred vision, cramps, hallucinations, hair loss, vomiting
Pamelor (nortriptyline hydrochloride) Diarrhea, fatigue, headache, decreased coordination
Paxil (paroxetine hydrochloride) Cold symptoms, drowsiness, nervousness, stomach pain
Prozac (fluoxetine hydrochloride) Bronchitis, drowsiness, fatigue, nausea, tremors
Sinequan (doxepin hydrochloride) Bruising, constipation, fluid retention, itching, increased heartbeat
Surmontil (trimipramine maleate) Disorientation, flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting
Tofranil (imipramine hydrochloride) Bleeding sores, fever, hives, decreased coordination
Travil Asthma, diarrhea, dizziness, fatigue, seizures
Wellbutrin (bupropion hydrochloride) Agitation, dry mouth, headache, nausea, rash
Zoloft (sertraline) Diarrhea, fainting, gas, headache, nervousness

drugs according to their established risks for use HealthFacts20 (February 1995):189.
during pregnancy. Category A: Controlled human
studies have demonstrated no fetal risk. Category Samuel Uretsky,PharmD

human studies; or adverse effects in animals, but
not in well-controlled human studies. Category C:
No adequate human or animal studies; or adverse
fetal effects in animal studies, but no available Antidepressants, tricyclic

Since their discovery in the 1950s,tricyclic antide-
pressants have been used to treat mental depression. Like
other antidepressant drugs,they reduce symptoms such
Interactions
as extreme sadness, hopelessness, and lack of energy.

lights.

Chronic—A word used to describe a long-lasting sudden and intense attacks of anxiety in certain sit-
condition. Chronic conditions often develop gradu- uations.

GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 263
Antidiabetic Drugs
Brand Name(Generic Name) Possible Common Side Effects Include:
Diabinese (chlorpropamide) Diarrhea, nausea, loss of appetite
Glucotrol (glipizide) Dizziness, fatigue, headache, nervousness
*Insulin Mild allergic reactions, decreased blood pressure, rash, shortness of breath
Micronase (glyburide) Nausea, heartburn, bloating
orinase (tolbutamide) Nausea, heartburn, bloating
*Insulin is the generic name for several brands which may be animal-based, human-based, or synthetic.
--- صفحة 278 ---
Purpose
KEY TERMS
Antidiarrheal drugs help control diarrhea and some
of the symptoms that go along with it.

--- Chunk 1560 ---
An average,
Blood sugar—The concentration of glucose in the
healthy person has anywhere from three bowel move-
blood.
ments a day to three a week,depending on that person’s
Glucose—A simple sugar that serves as the body’s diet. Normally the stool (the material that is passed in a
main source of energy. bowel movement) has a texture something like clay. With
diarrhea,bowel movements may be more frequent,and
Hormone—A substance that is produced in one
the texture of the stool is thin and sometimes watery.
part of the body, then travels through the blood-
stream to another part of the body where it has its Diarrhea is not a disease,but a symptom of some other
effect. problem.

--- Chunk 1561 ---
The symptom may be caused by eating or drink-
ing food or water that is contaminated with bacteria,virus-
Metabolism—All the physical and chemical
es,or parasites,or by eating something that is difficult to
changes that occur in cells to allow growth and
digest. People who have trouble digesting lactose (milk
maintain body functions. These include processes
sugar), for example, may get diarrhea if they eat dairy
that break down substances to yield energy and
products. Some cases of diarrhea are caused by stress,
processes that build up other substances necessary
while others are brought on by taking certain medicines.
for life.
Pregnancy category—A system of classifying
Description
drugs according to their established risks for use
during pregnancy.

and related compounds. Salicylates are used to not only controls diarrhea,but relieves the cramps that

Precautions
Diarrhea usually improves within 24-48 hours. If the
problem lasts longer or if it keeps coming back,diarrhea
Antidiarrheal drugs could be a sign of a more serious problem.

Purpose
KEY TERMS
Hemorrhoids are bulges in the veins that supply
blood to the skin and membranes of the area around the
Anus—The opening at the end of the intestine
anus. They may form for various reasons. Frequent heavy
through which solid waste (stool) passes as it
lifting,sitting for long periods,or straining to have bowel
leaves the body.
movements may put stresson anal tissues,which can lead
to hemorrhoids. Some women develop hemorrhoids dur- Rectum—The end of the intestine closest to the
ing pregnancyas the expanding uterus puts pressure on anus.
the anal tissues.

--- Chunk 1629 ---
The strain of labor and delivery can also

Hemorrhoids sometimes result from certain medical
problems,such as tumors pressing on the lower bowel.

from the rectum,especially after a bowel movement,and If rectal bleeding continues,check with a physician.

--- صفحة 291 ---
DANIELE BOVET (1907–1992)
A gifted researcher in therapeutic chemistry,
Daniele Bovet was born in Neuchatel, Switzerland, one
of four children of a professor of experimental educa-
tion. Bovet studied zoology and comparative anatomy
at the University of Geneva, receiving his doctor of sci-
ence degree in 1929. He then joined the Pasteur Insti-
tute in Paris, becoming director of the Laboratory of
Therapeutic Chemistry in 1936.
Bovet investigated histamine, thought to cause aller-
gy symptoms. No antagonist of histamine was known, so
Bovet—with his research student Anne-Marie Staub—
began studying substances that blocked hormones simi-
lar to histamine.

--- Chunk 1635 ---
By 1937 he had produced the first anti-
histamine, thymoxydiethylamine. Since this substance
was too toxic for human use, Bovet and Staub performed
thousands more experiments seeking less toxic antihista-
mines. This work formed the basis for the development
of subsequent clinically useful antihistamines.
Purpose
Antihistamines provide their primary action by
blocking histamine H at the receptor site. They have no
1
effect on rate of histamine release,nor do they inactivate
histamine. By inhibiting the activity of histamine,they
can reduce capillary fragility,which produces the erythe- addition to its role in reducing allergic reactions,may be
ma,or redness,associated with allergic reactions.

--- Chunk 1636 ---
They used as a nighttime sedative,for control of drug-induced
will also reduce histamine-induced secretions,including Parkinsonism,and,in liquid form,for control of coughs.
excessive tears and salivation. Additional effects vary Consult more detailed references for further information.
with the individual drug used. Several of the older drugs,
The second generation antihistamines have no cen-
called first-generation antihistamines, bind non-selec-
tral action, and are used only for treatment of allergic
tively to H receptors in the central nervous system as
1 reactions. These are divided into two chemical classes.

--- Chunk 1637 ---
well as to peripheral receptors,and can produce sedation,
Cetirizine (Zyrtec) is a piperazine derivative,and has a
inhibition of nausea and vomiting, and reduction of
slight sedative effect. Loratidine (Claritin) and fexofena-
motion sickness. The second-generation antihistamines
dine (Allegra) are members of the piperadine class and
bind only to peripheral H receptors,and reduce allergic
1 are essentially non-sedating.
response with little or no sedation.
The first-generation antihistamines may be divided Recommended dosage
into several chemical classes. The side effect profile,
Dosage varies with drug,patient and intended use.
which also determines the uses of the drugs,will vary by
Consult more detailed references for further information.
chemical class.

Antihistamines
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 277
KEY TERMS
Allergen—A substance that causes an allergy.
Anaphylaxis—A sudden, life-threatening allergic
reaction.
Hallucination—A false or distorted perception of
objects, sounds, or events that seems real.

--- Chunk 1640 ---
Halluci-
nations usually result from drugs or mental disor-
ders.
Histamine—A chemical released from cells in the
immune system as part of an allergic reaction.
Pregnancy category—A system of classifying
drugs according to their established risks for use
during pregnancy. Category A: Controlled human
studies have demonstrated no fetal risk. Category
B: Animal studies indicate no fetal risk, but no
human studies; or adverse effects in animals, but
not in well-controlled human studies. Category C:
No adequate human or animal studies; or adverse
fetal effects in animal studies, but no available
human data. Category D: Evidence of fetal risk,
but benefits outweigh risks. Category X: Evidence
of fetal risk. Risks outweigh any benefits.

--- Chunk 1641 ---
--- صفحة 292 ---

Samuel Uretsky,PharmD
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors(ACE
Antihyperlipidemic drugs see Cholesterol- inhibitors) act by inhibiting the production of angiotensin
reducing drugs II, a substance that both induces constriction of blood
vessels and retention of sodium, which leads to water
retention and increased blood volume.

--- Chunk 1647 ---
There are 10 ACE
inhibitors currently marketed in the United States,
including captopril (Capoten), benazepril (Lotensin),
enalapril (Vasotec),and quinapril (Acupril). The primary
Antihypertensive drugs
difference between these drugs is their onset and dura-
tion of action.

Purpose its production. Their actions are similar to the ACE

Michael V Zuck,PhD
Never take more than 10 mg of zolpidem in one 24-
hour period. Overdoses can lead to excessive sleepiness
or coma.

Definition
Anti-insomnia drugs are medicines that help people
Precautions

Zolpidem is meant only for short-term treatment of
insomnia. If sleep problems last more than seven to 10
Purpose

Physicians prescribe anti-insomnia drugs for short- lems could be a sign of another medical problem. Also,
term treatment of insomnia—a sleep problem in which this drug may lose its effectiveness when taken every

--- Chunk 1687 ---

be told to take it for one to two weeks before their trip and
Purpose for 4 weeks afterward,as well as for the whole time they
are away. It is important to follow these directions.

Cogentin (benztropine mesylate) Constipation, dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, rash
Eldepryl (selegiline hydrochloride) Abdominal and back pain, drowsiness, decreased coordination
Parlodel (bromocriptine mesylate) Constipation, decreased blood pressure, abdominal cramps
Sinemet CR Involuntary body movements, confusion, nausea, hallucinations

Anorexia—Lack or loss of appetite.

these typical symptoms in common: tremor, rigidity,
Anticholigerginc—An agent that blocks the

have demonstrated no fetal risk. Category B: Animal

Antipsychotic Drugs
Brand Name (Generic Name) Possible Common Side Effects Include:
Clozaril (clozapine) Seizures, agranulocytosis, dizziness, increased blood pressure
Compazine (prochlorperazine) Involuntary muscle spasms, dizziness, jitteriness, puckering of the mouth
Haldol (haloperidol) Involuntary muscle spasms, blurred vision, dehydration, headache, puckering of the mouth
Mellaril (thioridazine) Involuntary muscle spasms, constipation and diarrhea, sensitivity to light
Navane (thiothixene) Involuntary muscle spasms, dry mouth, rash, hives
Risperdal (risperidone) Involuntary muscle spasms, abdominal and chest pain, fever, headache
Stelazine (trifluoperazine hydrochloride) Involuntary muscle spasms, drowsiness, fatigue
Thorazine (chlorpromazine) Involuntary muscle spasms, labored breathing, fever, puckering of the mouth
Triavil Involuntary muscle spasms, disorientation, excitability, lightheadedness

Recommended dosage
Doses must be individualized based on the patient,
and use of interacting drugs. The optimum combinations
of antiretroviral drugs have not been determined,nor is
Antiretroviral drugs
there agreement on the stage of infection at which to start
treatment.
Definition
Antiretroviral drugs inhibit the reproduction of
Precautions
retroviruses—viruses composed of RNA rather than
DNA. The best known of this group is HIV, human Although the antiretroviral drugs fall into three
immunodeficiencyvirus,the causative agent of AIDS. groups,each drug has a unique pattern of adverse effects
and drug interactions. Since the drugs are used in various
Purpose combinations, the frequency and severity of adverse
effects will vary with the combination.

ly in multi-drug regimens, significantly slows disease
cause insomniain 3% of patients,however,when used

KEY TERMS
Antiviral drugs—Medicines that cure or control Pregnancy category—A system of classifying drugs
virus infections. according to their established risks for use during
pregnancy. Category A: Controlled human studies
Bioavailability—A measure of the amount of drug
have demonstrated no fetal risk. Category B: Animal
that is actually absorbed from a given dose.
studies indicate no fetal risk, but no human studies;
Immune system—The body’s natural defenses

Axid (nitzatidine) Diarrhea, headache, nausea and vomiting, sore throat
Carafate (sucralfate) Constipation, insomnia, hives, upset stomach, vomiting
Cytotec (misoprostol) Cramps, diarrhea, nausea, gas, headache, menstrual disorders (including
heavy bleeding and severe cramping)
Pepcid (famotidine) Constipation or diarrhea, dizziness, fatigue, fever
Prilosec (omeprazole) Nausea and vomiting, headache, diarrhea, abdominal pain
Tagamet (cimetidine) Headache, breast development in men, depression and disorientation
Zantac (ranitidine hydrochloride) Headache, constipation or diarrhea, joint pain

KEY TERMS Antiviral drugs
Definition
Antibiotic—Medicine used to treat infections.

--- Chunk 1853 ---
Antiviral drugs are medicines that cure or control
Enzyme—A type of protein, produced in the body,
virus infections.
that brings about or speeds up chemical reactions.
Gastrointestinal tract—The stomach, small intes-
tine and large intestine. Purpose

drome of the stomach is Zollinger-Ellison Syn- wide range of pathogens,antiviral agents tend to be nar-
drome, a syndrome consisting of fulminating row in spectrum,and have limited efficacy.

Although anxiety is related to fear,it is not the same
thing. Fear is a direct,focused response to a specific event
Resources
or object,and the person is consciously aware of it.

--- Chunk 1868 ---
Most
PERIODICALS people will feel fear if someone points a loaded gun at
Gray,Mary Ann. “Antiviral Medications.”Orthopaedic Nurs- them or if they see a tornado forming on the horizon. They
ing15 (November-December 1996):82. also will recognize that they are afraid. Anxiety, on the
other hand, is often unfocused, vague, and hard to pin
Samuel D. Uretsky,PharmD down to a specific cause. In this form it is called free-float-
ing anxiety. Sometimes anxiety being experienced in the
present may stem from an event or person that produced
painand fear in the past,but the anxious individual is not
consciously aware of the original source of the feeling. It
Anxiety is anxiety’s aspect of remoteness that makes it hard for
people to compare their experiences of it.

--- Chunk 1869 ---
Whereas most
Definition
people will be fearful in physically dangerous situations,
Anxiety is a multisystem response to a perceived and can agree that fear is an appropriate response in the
threat or danger. It reflects a combination of biochemical presence of danger,anxiety is often triggered by objects or
changes in the body, the patient’s personal history and events that are unique and specific to an individual. An
memory,and the social situation. As far as we know,anxi- individual might be anxious because of a unique meaning
ety is a uniquely human experience. Other animals clearly or memory being stimulated by present circumstances,not
know fear,but human anxiety involves an ability,to use because of some immediate danger.

--- Chunk 1870 ---
Another individual
memory and imagination to move backward and forward looking at the anxious person from the outside may be
in time,that animals do not appear to have. The anxiety truly puzzled as to the reason for the person’s anxiety.

Aortic aneurysm
Definition
An aneurysm is an abnormal bulging or swelling of
a portion of a blood vessel.

--- Chunk 1921 ---
The aorta,which can develop
these abnormal bulges,is the large blood vessel that car- weakness develops between the inner and outer layers of
ries oxygen-rich blood away from the heart to the rest of the aortic wall,a bulge results as blood from the interior
the body. of the vessel is pushed around the damaged region in the
wall and collects between these layers. This is called a
dissecting aneurysm because one layer is “dissected”or
Description
separated from another. If damage occurs to only the mid-
The aorta carries oxygen-rich blood to the body,and dle (muscular) layer of the vessel,a sack-like bulge can
is therefore called an artery. Because the aorta is an form; therefore,this is a saccular aneurysm.

--- Chunk 1922 ---
artery,its walls are made of up three layers; a thin inner
layer,a muscular middle layer (that gives the vessel its
Causes and symptoms
flexibility under pressure from the filling blood),and a
fiber-like outer layer that gives the vessel strength to not Aortic aneurysms occur in different portions of the
burst when the heart pumps blood to the body. aorta,which begins in the chest (at the heart) and travels
Aortic aneurysms occur when a weakness develops downward through the abdomen. Aneurysms found in
in part of the wall of the aorta; three basic types are usual- the region of the aorta within the chest are called thoracic
ly found. If all three layers of the vessel are affected and aortic aneurysms.

--- Chunk 1923 ---
Aneurysms that occur in the part of the
weakness develops along an extended area of the vessel, aorta within the abdomen are called abdominal aortic
the weakened area will appear as a large,bulging region aneurysms.
of blood vessel; this is called a fusiform aneurysm. If Thoracic aortic aneurysms do not usually produce
any noticeable symptoms. However, as the aneurysm
becomes larger, chest, shoulder, neck, lower back, or
abdominal paincan result. Abdominal aortic aneurysms
occur more often in men,and these aneurysms can cause
pain in the lower back, hips, and abdomen. A painful
abdominal aortic aneurysm usually means that the
aneurysm could burst very soon.

--- Chunk 1924 ---
Most abdominal aortic aneurysms are caused by
atherosclerosis, a condition caused when fat (mostly
cholesterol) carried in the blood builds up in the inner
wall of the aorta. As more and more fat attaches to the
aortic wall,the wall itself becomes abnormally weak and
often results in an aneurysm or bulge.
Aortic aneurysms are also caused by a breakdown of
the muscular middle layer of the artery wall, by high
blood pressure,by direct injury to the chest,and although
rare,by bacteria that can infect the aorta.

aneurysm

KEY TERMS
Rheumatic fever—A disease believed to be
caused by a bacterium named group A streptococ-
cus. This bacterium causes a sore “strep throat”
and can also result in fever. Infection by this bac-
terium can also damage the heart and its valves,
but how this takes place is not clearly understood.

Aortic valve stenosis
In cases of a severely malfunctioning valve that has
been untreated for a long time,surgery is the treatment of
Definition
choice,especially if the heart is not functioning normal-
ly. Human heart valves can be replaced with man-made When aortic valve stenosis occurs,the aortic valve,
valves or with valves taken from pig hearts. located between the aorta and left ventricle of the heart,
is narrower than normal size.

Description

for surgical valve replacement,it is important to replace A normal aortic valve,when open,allows the free
the faulty valve before the heart muscle itself is damaged flow of blood from the left ventricle to the aorta.
beyond recovery.

--- Chunk 1941 ---
When the valve narrows, as it does with stenosis,
blood flow is impeded. Because it is more difficult for
blood to flow through the valve, there is increased
Resources strain on the heart. This can cause the left ventricle to
BOOKS enlarge and malfunction, resulting in reduced blood

KEY TERMS
Aorta—The largest artery in the body, which
moves blood from the left ventricle to the rest of
the body.
ECG—Also called an electrocardiogram, it records
the electrical activity of the heart.
Echocardiogram—A procedure in which high fre-
quency sound waves harmlessly bounce off organs
in the body providing an image so one can deter-
mine their structure and function.

--- Chunk 1944 ---
Cardiac catheterization—A procedure in which
dye is injected through a tube or catheter into an
artery to more easily observe valves or blood ves-
sels seen on an x ray.

332 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
gnitset
ragpA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 332
As one of very few female medical students at
Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons
in New York during the early 1930s and one of the first
women to graduate from its medical school, Apgar knew
that her goal of becoming a surgeon would not be
achieved easily in a male-dominated profession.

--- Chunk 1958 ---
Reluc-
tantly, she switched her medical specialty to anesthesiol-
ogy, she embraced her new field with typical intelligence
and energy. At this time, anesthesiology was a relatively
new field, having been left by the doctors mostly to the
attention of nurses. Apgar realized immediately how
much in need of scientifically trained personnel was this
significant part of surgery, and she set out to make anes-
thesiology a separate medical discipline. By 1937, she
had become the fiftieth physician to be certified as an
anesthesiologist in the United States. The following year
she was appointed director of anesthesiology at the
Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, becoming the
first woman to head a department at that institution.

--- Chunk 1959 ---
As the attending anesthesiologist who assisted in the
delivery of thousands of babies during these years, Apgar
realized that infants had died from respiratory or circulato-
(AP/Wide World Photos.Reproduced by permission.)
ry complications that early treatment could have prevent-
ed. Apgar decided to bring her considerable research skills
to this childbirth dilemma, and her careful study resulted
in her publication of the Apgar Score System in 1952.
--- صفحة 347 ---
OTHER Aphasia is sometimes confused with other conditions

the Newborn Infant.<http://www.apgarfamily.com/ condition affect the muscles used in speaking rather than
Apgar_Paper.html>. language function itself.

--- Chunk 1960 ---

andbabycare.com>.
speaking,perhaps due to nerve damage. Speech apraxia is
PregnancyWeekly.com<http://www.pregnancyweekly.com>.
a speech disturbance in which language comprehension
and muscle control are retained,but the memory of how
Esther Csapo Rastegari,RN,BSN,EdM
to use the muscles to form words is not.
Causes and symptoms
Aphasia can develop after an individual sustains a
Aphasia brain injury from a stroke,head trauma,tumor,or infec-
tion,such as herpes encephalitis. As a result of this injury,
Definition the pathways for language comprehension or production
are disrupted or destroyed.

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 333
Aphasia
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 333
--- صفحة 348 ---
Speech is fairly unbroken, although individuals may
frequently correct themselves and words may be
skipped or repeated. Although able to understand spo-
ken language,it may also be difficult for the individual
with conduction aphasia to find the right word to
describe a person or object. The impact of this condi-
tion on reading and writing ability varies. As with other
types of aphasia,right-sided weakness or sensory loss
may be present.

--- Chunk 1967 ---
•Anomic or nominal aphasia primarily influences an
individual’s ability to find the right name for a person
or object. As a result,an object may be described rather
than named. Hearing comprehension,repetition,read-
ing, and writing are not affected, other than by this
inability to find the right name. Speech is fluent,except
for pauses as the individual tries to recall the right
name. Physical symptoms are variable,and some indi-
viduals have no symptoms of one-sided weakness or
sensory loss.
•Transcortical aphasia is caused by damage to the lan-
guage areas of the left hemisphere outside the primary
language areas. There are three types of aphasia:
transcortical motor aphasia,transcortical sensory apha-
sia,and mixed transcortical aphasia.

--- Chunk 1968 ---
All of the transcor-
tical aphasias are distinguished from other types by the
individual’s ability to repeat words, phrases, or sen-
tences. Other language functions may also be impaired
to varying degrees,depending on the extent and partic-
ular location of brain damage.

used are frequently unnecessary or even made-up.

334 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2

GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 334
Wernicke's area
Broca's area
Broca’s aphasia results from damage to the frontal lobe of
the language-dominant area of the brain.Individuals with
Broca’s aphasia may become mute or may be able to use
single-word statements or full sentences,although it may
require great effort.Wernicke’s aphasia is caused by damage
to the temporal lobe of the language-dominant area of the
brain.People with this condition speak in long,uninterrupt-
ed sentences,but the words used are often unnecessary and
unintelligible.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.

--- Chunk 1973 ---

Laproscopic appendectomy
When the surgeon conducts a laproscopic appendec-
tomy,four incisions,each about 1 in (2.5 cm) in length,
Appendectomy are made. One incision is near the umbilicus,or navel,
and one is between the umbilicus and the pubis. Two
Definition other incisions are smaller and are in the right side of the
lower abdomen. The surgeon then passes a camera and
Appendectomy is the surgical removal of the appen-
special instruments through these incisions. With the aid
dix. The appendix is a worm-shaped hollow pouch
of this equipment, the surgeon visually examines the
attached to the cecum,the beginning of the large intestine.
abdominal organs and identifies the appendix.

--- Chunk 1997 ---
Similarly,
the appendix is freed from all of its attachments and
Purpose
removed. The place where the appendix was formerly
Appendectomies are performed to treat appendici- attached, the cecum, is stitched. The appendix is
tis,an inflamed and infected appendix. removed through one of the incisions. The instruments
are removed and then all of the incisions are closed.
Precautions

Mary Jeanne Krob,MD,FACS
Appendicitis
Definition
Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix,
which is the worm-shaped pouch attached to the cecum,
the beginning of the large intestine.

--- Chunk 2009 ---
The appendix has no
known function in the body,but it can become diseased. disease, ruptured ovarian follicles, ruptured ovarian
Appendicitis is a medical emergency, and if it is left cysts, tubal pregnancies, and endometriosis. Various
untreated the appendix may rupture and cause a poten- forms of stomach upset and bowel inflammation may
tially fatal infection. also mimic appendicitis.
The treatment for acute (sudden,severe) appendici-
Description tis is an appendectomy,surgery to remove the appendix.
Because of the potential for a life-threatening ruptured
Appendicitis is the most common abdominal emer-
appendix,persons suspected of having appendicitis are
gency found in children and young adults. One person in
often taken to surgery before the diagnosis is certain.

--- Chunk 2010 ---
15 develops appendicitis in his or her lifetime. The inci-
dence is highest among males aged 10-14, and among
females aged 15-19. More males than females develop Causes and symptoms
appendicitis between pubertyand age 25. It is rare in the
The causes of appendicitis are not well understood,
elderly and in children under the age of two.
but it is believed to occur as a result of one or more of

Bone health
The first part of AK is muscle testing,which is used
•neck/low back painand sciatica
to help diagnose what part of the body is functioning
•whiplash
abnormally. Muscle testing involves putting the body
into a position that requires a certain muscle to remain •frozen shoulder
contracted,and then applying pressure against the mus-
Joint health
cle.

--- Chunk 2030 ---
The testing does not measure strength but is meant to
•carpal tunnel syndrome
reveal stresses and imbalances in the body through the
tension in the muscle. The test evaluates the ability of a •arthritis (including rheumatoid arthritis)
controlling system (like the nervous system) to adapt the
•sports injuries
muscle to meet the changing pressure of the examiner’s
Muscle health
test. AK practitioners also examine structural factors
such as posture,gait,and range of motion.

Arbovirus encephalitis virus primarily strikes 5-18 year olds, with a lower
degree of permanent brain damage.
Definition
Encephalitisis a serious inflammation of the brain.

He wrote about his use
348 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
yparehtamorA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:42 PM Page 348
--- صفحة 363 ---
of essential oils and their healing and antiseptic properties,
in his 1964 book Aromatherapie,traitement des maladies
par les essences des plantes,which popularized the use of
essential oils for medical and psychiatric treatment through-
out France. Later,French biochemist Mauguerite Maury
popularized the cosmetic benefits of essential oils,and in
1977 Robert Tisserand wrote the first English language
book on the subject,The Art of Aromatherapy,which intro-
duced massage as an adjunct treatment to aromatherapy and
sparked its popularity in the United Kingdom.
In aromatherapy,essential oils are carefully selected
for their medicinal properties.

--- Chunk 2054 ---
As essential oils are
absorbed into the bloodstream through application to the
skin or inhalation,their active components trigger certain
pharmalogical effects (e.g.,pain relief).
In addition to physical benefits, aromatherapy has
strong psychological benefits. The volatility of an oil,or
the speed at which it evaporates in open air,is thought to
be linked to the specific psychological effect of an oil. As
a rule of thumb,oils that evaporate quickly are consid-
ered emotionally uplifting,while slowly-evaporating oils
are thought to have a calming effect.
Essential oils commonly used in aromatherapy treat-
ment include: •Peppermint (Mentha piperita). Relaxes and soothes the

--- Chunk 2072 ---
Definition
Asthmatic individuals should not use steam inhala-
tion for aromatherapy,as it can aggravate their condition. An arrhythmia is an abnormality in the heart’s rhythm,
or heartbeat pattern. The heartbeat can be too slow,too fast,
Essential oils are flammable, and should be kept
have extra beats,skip a beat,or otherwise beat irregularly.
away from heat sources.

Many arrhythmias do not require any treatment. For

--- صفحة 374 ---
move the joint into a series of positions, keeping still
between positioning. Sometimes,the patient will experience
some tingling or discomfort during the procedure,which is
normal and due to the contrast. Following fluoroscopic
tracking of the contrast,standard x rays of the area may also
be taken. The entire procedure will last about one hour.

--- Chunk 2121 ---
Preparation
It is important to discuss any known sensitivity to
local anesthetics or iodine prior to this procedure. A
physician should explain the procedure and the risks
associated with contrast agents and ask the patient to sign
an informed consent. If iodine contrast will be adminis-
tered,the patient may be instructed not to eat before the
exam. The timeframe of fastingmay extend from only
90 minutes prior to the exam up to the night before.
There is no other preparation necessary.
need for joint replacement(prostheses). The most com-
Aftercare
monly studied joints are the knee and shoulder.
The affected joint should be rested for approximate-
ly 12 hours following the procedure.

KEY TERMS
The goal of arthroplasty is to restore the function of a
stiffened joint and relieve pain. Two types of arthroplastic

a needle.

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 369
Asbestosis
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 369
--- صفحة 384 ---
ical histories can identify occupations,hobbies,or other sit-
uations likely to involve exposure to asbestos fibers.

--- Chunk 2177 ---
X rays can show shadows or spots on the lungs or an
indistinct or shaggy outline of the heart that suggests the
presence of asbestosis. Blood tests are used to measure
concentrations of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Pulmonary
function tests can be used to assess a patient’s ability to
inhale and exhale, and a computed tomography scan
(CT) of the lungs can show flat,raised patches associated
with advanced asbestosis.
Treatment
The goal of treatment is to help patients breathe
more easily, prevent colds and other respiratory infec-
tions, and control complications associated with
advanced disease. Ultrasonic,cool-mist humidifiers or
New Jersey, and most of them had worked in the con- controlled coughing can loosen bronchial secretions.
struction or shipbuilding trades.

--- Chunk 2178 ---
Regular exercise helps maintain and improve lung
capacity. Although temporary bed rest may be recom-
mended,patients are encouraged to resume their regular
Causes and symptoms
activities as soon as they can.

asbestos dust that cling to workers’clothes.

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 371
Ascites
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 371
--- صفحة 386 ---
Persons who have systemic lupus erythematosus
but do not have liver disease or portal hypertension occa-
sionally develop ascites. Depressed thyroid activity
sometimes causes pronounced ascites,but inflammation
of the pancreas (pancreatitis) rarely causes significant
accumulations of fluid.
Symptoms
Small amounts of fluid in the abdomen do not usual-
ly produce symptoms.

--- Chunk 2188 ---
Massive accumulations may cause:
•rapid weight gain
•abdominal discomfort and distention
•shortness of breath
•swollen ankles
Diagnosis
Skin stretches tightly across an abdomen that con-
tains large amounts of fluid. The navel bulges or lies flat,
and the fluid makes a dull sound when the doctor taps the
abdomen. Ascitic fluid may cause the flanks to bulge.
Physical examinationgenerally enables doctors to
distinguish ascites from pregnancy,intestinal gas,obe-
sity,or ovarian tumors. Ultrasound or computed tomog-
raphy scans (CT) can detect even small amounts of
fluid. Laboratory analysis of fluid extracted by inserting
in blood plasma. It functions to keep fluid inside the
a needle through the abdominal wall (diagnostic para-
blood vessels.

--- Chunk 2189 ---
centesis) can help identify the cause of the accumulation.

Causes and symptoms
Aspergillosis
Aspergillusis a fungus that is found almost everywhere,
Definition but particularly in soil, water, decaying vegetation, and
stored grain. The fungus has also been cultured from ventila-
Aspergillosis refers to several forms of disease
tion systems and may be stirred up during building renova-
caused by a fungus in the genus Aspergillus.

--- Chunk 2204 ---
Aspergillo-
tions. The species most commonly identified in patients with
sis fungal infections can occur in the ear canal, eyes,
confirmed disease are A. fumigatusand A. flavus.
nose,sinus cavities,and lungs. In some individuals,the
Airborne Aspergillusspores enter the body primarily
infection can even invade bone and the membranes that
enclose the brain and spinal cord (meningitis). through inhalation but can also lodge in the ear or eye.
Normally functioning immune systems are generally able
to cope without consequent development of aspergillosis.

--- Chunk 2205 ---

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 375
Aspergillosis
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 375
--- صفحة 390 ---
of the same drugs used to treat asthma,such as systemic
steroids. Long-term therapy may be required,however,to
prevent recurrence.

--- Chunk 2211 ---
Antifungal agents are not recom-
mended in the treatment of ABPA. In cases of aspergillo-
ma, it may become necessary to surgically remove or
reduce the size of a fungal mass,especially if the patient
continues to spit up blood. In aspergillosis cases affecting
the nose and nasal sinuses,surgery may also be required.
In non-ABPA cases,the use of antifungal drugs may
be indicated. In such cases,amphotericin B (Fungizone)
is the first-line therapy. The prescribed dose will depend
on the patient’s condition but usually begins with a small
test dose and then escalates. Less than one-third of
patients are likely to respond to amphotericin B,and its
side effects often limit its use.

--- Chunk 2212 ---
For patients who do not
respond to oral amphotericin B,another option is a dif-
ferent formulation of the same drug called liposomal
amphotericin B.
For patients who fail to respond or who cannot toler-
ate amphotericin B, another drug called itraconazole
(Sporanox), given 400-600 mg daily, has also been
approved. Treatment generally lasts about 3 months. Giv-
ing itraconazole can produce adverse reactions if pre-
scribed in combination with certain other drugs by
increasing the concentrations of both drugs in the blood
cal, specific, and rapid blood test that would confirm and creating a potentially life-threatening situation. Even
Aspergillusinfection. antacidscan significantly affect itraconazole levels.

--- Chunk 2213 ---
As a
result, drug levels must be continually monitored to

384 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
msitamgitsA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 384
--- صفحة 399 ---
(hyperopia) may see a dot as a blurred circle. A person
with astigmatism may see the same dot as a blurred oval
or frankfurter-shaped blur.
Some cases of astigmatism are caused by problems
in the lens of the eye. Minor variations in the curvature of
the lens can produce minor degrees of astigmatism
(lenticular astigmatism). In these patients,the cornea is
usually normal in shape. Infants, as a group, have the
least amount of astigmatism. Astigmatism may increase
during childhood,as the eye is developing.

--- Chunk 2264 ---
Causes and symptoms
The main symptom of astigmatism is blurring. Peo-
ple can also experience headaches and eyestrain. Parents
can notice that a child may have astigmatism when the
child can see some part of a pattern or picture more clear-
ly than others. For example,lines going across may seem
clearer than lines going up and down.
Regular astigmatism can be caused by the weight of
the upper eyelid resting on the eyeball creating distortion,
surgical incisions in the cornea,trauma or scarring to the
cornea,the presence of tumors in the eyelid,or a develop-
mental factor. Irregular astigmatism can be caused by scar-
ring or keratoconus. Keratoconus is a condition in which
the cornea thins and becomes cone shaped. It usually
occurs around pubertyand is more common in women.

--- Chunk 2265 ---
Although the causes of keratoconus are unknown,it may
be hereditary or a result of chronic eye rubbing,as in peo-
ple with allergies. The center of the cone may not be in larger area of the cornea. It can measure the central area
line with the center of the cornea. Diabetes can play a role and mid-periphery of the cornea. A keratoscope projects
in the development of astigmatism. High blood sugar lev- a series of concentric light rings onto the cornea. Mis-
els can cause shape changes in the lens of the eye. This shapen areas of the cornea are revealed by noting areas

when the diabetic has started treatment to control their cornea.

--- صفحة 401 ---
KEY TERMS
Rolfing—Developed by Dr. Ida Rolf (1896–1979),
rolfing is a systematic approach to relieving stress
patterns and dysfunctions in the body’s structure
through the manipulation of the highly pliant myofa-
cial (connective) tissue. It assists the body in reorga-
nizing its major segments into vertical alignment.
Preparations
No special preparation need be taken.
Precautions
No special precautions are necessary when partici-
pating.

--- Chunk 2275 ---
Side effects
No undesirable side effects are reported. Usually
clients report a diminution of tension, improved body
movement,and an enhanced feeling of well being.
Research and general acceptance
Aston-Patterning is an outgrowth of Rolfing,which
has been shown to be of benefit in a limited number of
controlled studies. Little controlled research has been done
on the either benefits or limitations of Aston-Patterning. Its
•Movement education and bodywork, including mas-
claims have been neither proven nor disproved,although
sage, myofacial release, and arthrokinetics, to help
anecdotally many clients report relief from pain and ten-
release tension and make new movement patterns easier.
sion and also improved body movement.

--- Chunk 2276 ---
•Post-testing,when pre-testing movements are repeated,
allowing the client to feel the changes that have taken Resources
place and integrate them into daily life.
ORGANIZATIONS
Aston-Patterning requires more participation from The Aston Training Center. P. O. Box 3568,Incline Village,
the client than many bodywork techniques. The massage NV 89450. 775-831-8228. Astonpat@aol.com <http://
aspect of Aston-Patterning is designed around a three- www.aston-patterning.com>.
dimensional, non-compressive touch that releases pat-
terns of tension in the body. It is gentler than Rolfing. Tish Davidson
Myokinetics uses touch to release tension in the face and
neck. Arthrokinetics addresses tension at bones and Astrocytoma see Brain tumor
joints.

--- Chunk 2277 ---
This massage is accompanied by education about
how new movement patterns may be established.
In addition to Aston-Patterning sessions,clients are
also helped to examine their environment for factors,such
as seating or sleeping arrangements,that may limit their Ataxia-telangiectasia
body function and introduce tension. Finally,they may
Definition
choose to participate in the Aston fitness training program
that includes loosening techniques based on self-massage, Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), also called Louis-Bar
toning,stretching,and cardiovascular fitness. syndrome,is a rare,genetic neurological disorder of child-
GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 387
Ataxia-telangiectasia
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 387
JUDITH ASTON
Judith Aston was born in Long Beach, California.

--- Chunk 2278 ---
She graduated from University of California at Los Ange-
les with a B.A. and a M.F.A. in dance. Her interest in
movement arose from working as a dancer. In 1963
Aston established her first movement education pro-
gram for dancers, actors, and athletes at Long Beach
City College.
Five years later, while recovering from injuries sus-
tained during two consecutive automobile accidents,
Aston met Ida Rolf, the developer of Rolfing. Aston
began working for Rolf, teaching a movement education
program called Rolf-Aston Structural Patterning that
emphasized using the body with minimum effort and
maximum precision.
In time, Rolf and Aston’s views on movement
diverged, and the partnership was dissolved in 1977.

--- Chunk 2279 ---
Aston formed her own company called the Aston Para-
digm Corporation in Lake Tahoe, California. This com-
pany provides training and certification for Aston practi-
tioners. She also began exploring how environmental
conditions affect body movement, foreshadowing the
ergonomic movement in the workplace that developed
in the 1990s. Over time, Aston has expanded her move-
ment work to include a fitness program for older adults.
Today, Judith Aston serves as director of Aston Paradigm
Corporation.
--- صفحة 402 ---
hood that progressively destroys part of the motor control and eight, telangiectases, or tiny, red “spider” veins,
area of the brain,leading to a lack of balance and coordina- appear on the cheeks and ears and in the eyes.
tion.

--- Chunk 2280 ---

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 389
Atelectasis
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 389
--- صفحة 404 ---
inhaled objects can also cause obstruction of the airway,
leading to atelectasis.
Anyone undergoing chest or abdominal surgery
using general anesthesia is at risk to develop atelectasis,
since breathing is often shallow after surgery to avoid
pain from the surgical incision. Any significant decrease
in airflow to the alveoli contributes to pooling of secre-
tions,which in turn can cause infection.

--- Chunk 2292 ---
Chest injuries
causing shallow breathing,including fractured ribs,can
cause atelectasis. Common symptoms of atelectasis
include shortness of breath and decreased chest wall
expansion. If atelectasis only afects a small area of the
lung, symptoms are ususally minimal. If the condition
affects a large area of the lung and develops quickly,the
individual may turn blue (cyanotic) or pale,have extreme
shortness of breath, and feel a stabbing pain on the
affected side. Feverand increased heart rate may be pre-
sent if infection accompanies atelectasis.
Diagnosis
To diagnose atelectasis,a doctor starts by recording
the patient’s symptoms and performing a thorough phys-
ical examination.

--- Chunk 2293 ---
When the doctor listens to the lungs
Description through a stethoscope (ausculation), diminished or
bronchial breath sounds may be heard. By tapping on the
Atelectasis can result from an obstruction (block-
chest (percussion) while listening through the stetho-
age) of the airways that affects tiny air scas called alve-
scope,the doctor can often tell if the lung is collapsed. A

chest x ray that shows an airless area in the lung con-
supply. They are important for lung function,since their
firms the diagnosis of atelectasis. If an obstruction of the
purpose is the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Coronary arteries—The two main arteries that
provide blood to the heart. The coronary arteries Atherectomy see Angioplasty
surround the heart like a crown, coming out of the
aorta, arching down over the top of the heart, and
dividing into two branches. These are the arteries
where coronary artery disease occurs.

vessel. Definition
Atherosclerosis is the build up of a waxy plaque on
the inside of blood vessels. In Greek,atheremeans gruel,
and sklerosmeans hard.

to keep a blocked artery open.
Treatment
Treatment includes lifestyle changes,lipid-lowering
drugs,percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty,
Alternative treatment
and coronary artery bypass surgery. Atherosclerosis
requires lifelong care. Alternative therapies that focus on diet and lifestyle
can help prevent,retard,or reverse atherosclerosis. Herbal

Carol A. Turkington The changes in the heart beat caused by the electri-
cal conduction system of the heart are detectable on an
electrocardiogram. Many of the changes seen in athletic
heart syndrome mimic those of various heart diseases.
Careful examination must be made to distinguish heart
Athletic heart syndrome disease from athletic heart syndrome.

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 401
Atkins
diet
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 401
DR. ROBERT C. ATKINS (1930– )
specialty in cardiology. As an internist and cardiologist
he developed the Atkins Diet in the early 1970s.

--- Chunk 2355 ---
The diet
is a ketogenic diet—a high protein, high fat, and very
low carbohydrate regimen resulting in ketosis. It empha-
sizes meat, cheese, and eggs, while discouraging foods
such as bread, pasta, fruit, and sugar. It first came to pub-
lic attention in 1972 with the publication of Dr.Atkins’
Diet Revolution. The book quickly became a bestseller
but unlike most other fad diet books, this one has
remained popular. At last count, it had been reprinted 28
times and sold more than 10 million copies worldwide.
Since then, Atkins has authored a number of other books
on his diet theme, including Dr.Atkins’New Diet Revo-
lution (1992), Dr. Atkins’ Quick and Easy New Diet
Cookbook (1997), and The Vita-Nutrient Solution:
Nature’s Answer to Drugs(1998).

--- Chunk 2356 ---
Atkins has seen about 60,000 patients in his more
than 30 years of practice. He has also appeared on numer-
ous radio and television talk shows, has his own syndicat-
ed radio program, Your Health Choices, and authors the
monthly newsletter Dr.Atkins’Health Revelations. Atkins
has received the World Organization of Alternative Medi-
(AP/Wide World Photos.Reproduced by permission.)
cine’s Recognition of Achievement Award and been
named the National Health Federation’s Man of the Year.
Dr. Robert C. Atkins graduated from the University He is director of the Atkins Center for Complementary
of Michigan in 1951 and received his medical degree Medicine which he founded in the early 1980s. The center
from Cornell University Medical School in 1955 with a is located at 152 E. 55th St.

--- Chunk 2357 ---
, New York, NY 10022.
--- صفحة 416 ---

and uric acid. A glucose tolerance test is also recom- and cellulose.
mended.
Hypertension—Abnormally high arterial blood
pressure, which if left untreated can lead to heart
disease and stroke.

Atopic dermatitis
Definition
Eczema is a general term used to describe a variety
of conditions that cause an itchy, inflamed skin rash.
Atopic dermatitis, a form of eczema, is a non-conta-
gious disorder characterized by chronically inflamed
skin and sometimes intolerable itching.

--- Chunk 2363 ---
Description
Atopic dermatitis refers to a wide range of diseases
that are often associated with stressand allergic disor-
ders that involve the respiratory system,like asthmaand
hay fever. Although atopic dermatitis can appear at any
age, it is most common in children and young adults.
Symptoms usually abate before the age of 25 and do not
affect the patient’s general health.
About one in ten babies develop a form of atopic
dermatitis called infantile eczema. Characterized by skin
that oozes and becomes encrusted,infantile eczema most
often occurs on the face and scalp. The condition usually
improves before the child’s second birthday,and medical
attention can keep symptoms in check until that time.

--- Chunk 2364 ---
When atopic dermatitis develops after infancy,
inflammation, blistering, oozing, and crusting are less
•ankles
pronounced. The patient’s sores become dry,turn from
•wrists
red to brownish-gray,and skin may thicken and become
scaly. In dark-skinned individuals, this condition can •face
cause the complexion to lighten or darken. Itching asso-
•neck
ciated with this condition is usually worst at night. It can
be so intense that patients scratch until their sores bleed, •upper chest
sometimes causing scarring and infection.

of the United States,and about 80% of the people who

--- صفحة 418 ---
•use of drugs that suppress immune-system activity
Certain foods, such as peanuts, cow’s milk, eggs,
and fish, can trigger symptoms of atopic dermatitis.

--- Chunk 2367 ---
A
small percentage of patients with atopic dermatitis find
that their symptoms worsen after having been exposed to
dust, feather pillows, rough-textured fabrics, or other
materials to which dust adheres.
Diagnosis
Diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is usually based on
the patient’s symptoms and personal and family health
history. Skin tests do not generally provide reliable infor-
mation about this condition.
Treatment
Atopic dermatitis cannot be cured,but the severity
and duration of symptoms can be controlled. A dermatol-
ogist should be consulted when symptoms first appear,
and is likely to recommend warm baths to loosen
encrusted skin, followed by applications of petroleum
jelly or vegetable shortening to prevent the skin’s natural
moisture from escaping.

--- Chunk 2368 ---
Externally applied (topical) steroids or preparations
containing coal tar can relieve minor itching,but coal tar
has an unpleasant odor,stains clothes,and may increase
skin-cancer risk. Excessive use of steroid creams in
young children can alter growth. Pregnant women should
not use products that contain coal tar. Topical steroids can
cause itching, burning, acne, permanent stretch marks,
and thinning and spotting of the skin. Applying topical
steroids to the area around the eyes can cause glaucoma.
Oral antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine
(Benadryl),can relieve symptoms of allergy-related atopic
broken,there is also a risk of developing skin infections
dermatitis.

become more serious.

Infant Adult
Atopic dermatitis can erupt on any part of the skin.In
infants,it often appears on the face,scalp,and knees,while
it develops on the elbows,neck,back of the knees,and
ankles in adults.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)

Atrial ectopic beats
Prognosis
Definition Occasional AEB usually have no significance. If
they increase in frequency,they can lead to atrial tachy-
Atrial ectopic beats (AEB) refers to a contraction of
cardia or fibrillation and to a decrease in cardiac output.
the upper heart chamber which occurs before it would be
expected. Atrial ectopic beats are also known as prema-
ture atrial beats,premature atrial complex (PAC),or atri-
Prevention
al extrasystole.
AEB cannot usually be prevented. Aggravating fac-
Description tors can be addressed, like excessive stimulants, and
uncontrolled pulmonary disorders.

--- Chunk 2381 ---
An AEB is usually a harmless disturbance in the
normal rhythm of the heart. It can occur only occasional-
ly,in a regular pattern,or several may occur in sequence
Resources
and then disappear. Most often,the person is unaware of
the event. BOOKS
McGoon,Michael D.,ed. Mayo Clinic Heart Book:The Ulti-
mate Guide to Heart Health.New York:William Morrow
Causes and symptoms
and Co.,Inc.,1993.
As people age,extra beats tend to happen more fre-
quently even in perfectly healthy individuals. AEB may ORGANIZATIONS
be triggered or increased by stress,caffeine,smoking, American Heart Association. 7320 Greenville Ave. Dallas,TX
and some medicines. Cold remedies containing ephedrine 75231. (214) 373-6300. <http://www.americanheart.org>.

dence of atrial ectopic beats. AEB may also be the result Dorothy Elinor Stonely

blood supply to that area of the heart.

Atrial fibrillation and flutter
•open heart surgery

rhythms in which the atria,or upper chambers of the heart, •a pulse that feels like the heart is skipping,racing,jump-
are out of sync with the ventricles,or lower chambers of ing,or is irregular
the heart. In atrial fibrillation,the atria “quiver”chaotical-
•low energy
ly and the ventricles beat irregularly. In atrial flutter,the
atria beat regularly and faster than the ventricles.

KEY TERMS Atrial septal defect
Definition
Arrhythmia—A variation in the normal rhythm of
the heart beat.

--- Chunk 2396 ---
Atrial fibrillation and flutter are two An atrial septal defect is an abnormal opening in the
types of arrhythmia. wall separating the left and right upper chambers (atria)
of the heart.
Atria—The two small upper chambers of the heart
that receive blood from the lungs and the body.
Stroke—A brain attack caused by a sudden disrup- Description
tion of blood flow to the brain, in this case

because of a blood clot.

--- Chunk 2397 ---
child is born with a hole between the left and right atria.
This abnormal opening is called an atrial septal defect
and causes blood from the left atrium to flow into the
right atrium.

blood within the heart. If the heart has an opening
Attapulgite see Antidiarrheal drugs
between the atria,oxygen-rich blood from the left atrium
enters the right atrium.

--- Chunk 2403 ---
Through cardiac catheterization,
doctors can detect the higher-than-normal amount of oxy-
gen in the heart’s right atrium, right ventricle, and the
large blood vessels that carry blood to the lungs,where
the blood would normally subsequently get its oxygen.

disorder (ADHD)

medical treatments by the age of two. If this dose not hap-

Some patients can have the defect fixed by having an
clam-shaped plug placed over the opening. This plug is a
Description
man-made device that is put in place through a catheter
inserted into the heart. ADHD,also known as hyperkinetic disorder (HKD)
outside of the United States,is estimated to affect 3-9%
of children, and afflicts boys more often than girls.

the right type of therapy,which might include hearing aids,
corrective surgery,or speech therapy,can be prescribed.
Precautions
Testing with audiometry equipment is simple and
painless. No special precautions are required.
Description
A trained audiologist (a specialist in detecting hear-
ing loss) uses an audiometer to conduct audiometry test-
ing. This equipment emits sounds or tones,like musical
notes,at various frequencies,or pitches,and at differing
volumes or levels of loudness. Testing is usually done in
a soundproof testing room.

--- Chunk 2428 ---
The person being tested wears a set of headphones
that blocks out other distracting sounds and delivers a
test tone to one ear at a time. At the sound of a tone,the
patient holds up a hand or finger to indicate that the
The National Attention Deficit Disorder Association. (ADDA).
9930 Johnnycake Ridge Road,Suite 3E,Mentor,OH sound is detected. The audiologist lowers the volume and
44060. (800) 487-2282. <http://www.add.org>. repeats the sound until the patient can no longer detect it.
This process is repeated over a wide range of tones or
Paula Anne Ford-Martin
frequencies from very deep,low sounds,like the lowest
note played on a tuba,to very high sounds,like the ping-
Attention deficit disorder see Attention-
ing of a triangle. Each ear is tested separately.

--- Chunk 2429 ---
It is not
deficit/Hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) unusual for levels of sensitivity to sound to differ from
one ear to the other.
Atypical mycobacterial infections see
Mycobacterial infections, atypical A second type of audiometry testing uses a headband
rather than headphones. The headband is worn with small
Atypical pneumonia see Mycoplasma
plastic rectangles that fit behind the ears to conduct sound
infections through the bones of the skull. The patient being tested
senses the tones that are transmitted as vibrations through
the bones to the inner ear. As with the headphones, the
tones are repeated at various frequencies and volumes.
The results of the audiometry test may be recorded
Audiometry
on a grid or graph called an audiogram.

Definition generally set up with low frequencies or tones at one end
and high ones at the other end,much like a piano key-

board. Low notes are graphed on the left and high notes
hear various sound frequencies. The test is performed
on the right. The graph also charts the volume of the

nician called an audiologist.
units called decibels. Most of the sounds associated with
normal speech patterns are generally spoken in the range
Purpose of 20-50 decibels.

An adult with normal hearing can
detect tones between 0-20 decibels.

ALFRED TOMATIS (1920– )
Alfred Tomatis is also the inventor of the Electronic •Communication begins in the womb. As early as the

basis of Tomatis’work is a series of principles that follow: vous system of the baby to develop.
•The most important purpose of the ear is to adapt sound

•Sound is conducted via both air and bone. It can be

Among these are:
•Just as seeing is not the same as looking,hearing is not
the same as listening. Hearing is passive. Listening is •Phonetic decoding, a problem that occurs when the

416 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
gniniart
noitargetni
yrotiduA
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A 10/22/03 1:43 PM Page 416
early in his career treated some of his parents’ fellow
opera singers.

--- Chunk 2440 ---
From these experiences with the sound of
music, he developed the principle that has come to be
known as the Tomatis Effect, i.e. that the human voice can
only sing what it hears.
Tomatis has been called the Einstein of the ear. It was
his research that made the world aware that the ears of an
infant in utero are already functioning at four and half
months of age. Just as the umbilical cord provides nour-
ishment to the unborn infant’s body, Tomatis postulated
that the sound of the mother’s voice is also a nutrient
heard by the fetus. This sound literally charges and stimu-
lates the growth of the brain.
Tomatis took this further, into the realm of language.
Tomatis concluded that the need to communicate and to
be understood are among our most basic needs.

--- Chunk 2441 ---
He was a
pioneer in perceiving that language problems convert into
social problems for people. “Language is what character-
izes man and makes him different from other creatures,”
Tomatis is quoted as saying. The techniques he developed
to teach people how to listen effectively are international-
(Photograph by V.Brynner.Gamma Liaison.Reproduced by ly respected tools used in the treatment of autism, atten-
permission.) tion-deficit disorder, and other learning disabilities.

--- Chunk 2442 ---
His listening program, the invention of the Electronic
Internationally renowned French otolaryngologist, Ear, and his work with the therapeutic use of sound and
psychologist, educator and inventor Alfred Tomatis per- music for the past fifty years have made Tomatis arguably
ceived the importance of sound and hearing early in his the best known and most successful ear specialist in the
career. He took his degree as a Doctor of Medicine from world. There are more than two hundred Tomatis Centers
the University of Paris and specialized in ear, nose and worldwide, treating a vast variety of problems related to
throat medicine. The son of two opera singers, Tomatis the ability to hear.

--- Chunk 2443 ---

reducing specific symptoms. Because the symptoms vary

significantly with proper treatment.

This can cause the pilot to have tun-

situations,the military requires fighter pilots to wear spe-
cial flight suits, or G suits, which have compartments
that fill with air or fluid to keep blood from pooling in
the lower body.

Personality disorders
Another health threat to space travelers is radiation.
Harmful rays can alter the DNA in human cells and Avulsions see Wounds
cause cancer. Excess radiation also can weaken the
immune system. To prevent these problems,physicians
may give astronauts nutritional supplements. For exam-
ple,research has show that n-3 fatty acids found in fish
oil reduce DNA damage.

DEEPAK CHOPRA (1946– )
Tufts University and Boston University schools of medi-
cine—while establishing a very successful private prac-
tice. By the time he was thirty-five, Chopra had become
chief of staff at New England Memorial Hospital.
Disturbed by Western medicine’s reliance on med-
ication, he began a search for alternatives and discovered
one in the teachings of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, an
Indian spiritualist who had gained a cult following in the
late sixties teaching Transcendental Meditation (TM).
Chopra began practicing TM fervently and eventually met
the Maharishi.

--- Chunk 2516 ---
In 1985 Chopra established the Ayurvedic
Health Center for Stress Management and Behavioral
Medicine in Lancaster, Massachusetts, where he began
his practice of integrating the best aspects of Eastern and
Western medicine.
In 1993, he published Creating Affluence: Wealth
Consciousness in the Field of All Possibilities, and the
enormously successful best seller, Ageless Body,Timeless
Mind. In the latter he presents his most radical thesis: that
aging is not the inevitable deterioration of organs and
mind that we have been traditionally taught to think of it
(AP/Wide World Photos.Reproduced by permission.) as. It is a process that can be influenced, slowed down,
and even reversed with the correct kinds of therapies,
almost all of which are self-administered or self-taught.

--- Chunk 2517 ---
Deepak Chopra was born in India and studied medi- He teaches that applying a regimen of nutritional bal-
cine at the All India Institute of Medical Science. He left ance, meditation, and emotional clarity characterized by
his home for the United States in 1970 and completed such factors as learning to easily and quickly express
residencies in internal medicine and endocrinology. He anger, for instance, can lead to increased lifespans of up
went on to teaching posts at major medical institutions— to 120 years.

Bach flower remedies see Flower remedies bacillary angiomatosis are firm and don’t turn white when

Bacteroides infection see Anaerobic
infections The most effective treatment of bad breath is to treat
the cause. Poor oral hygienecan be improved by regular
brushing and flossing,as well as regular dental checkups.
Gentle brushing of the tongue should be part of daily oral
hygiene. In addition to good oral hygiene,the judicious
use of mouthwashes is helpful. Mouth dryness,experi-
Bad breath

ications and medical conditions, can contribute to bad
Definition

Balance and coordination tests
Definition
Balance is the ability to maintain a position.

--- Chunk 2561 ---
Coordi-
nation is the capacity to move through a complex set of
movements. Balance and coordination depend on the
interaction of multiple body organs and systems includ-
ing the eyes,ears,brain and nervous system,cardiovas-
cular system,and muscles. Tests or examination of any
or all of these organs or systems may be necessary to
determine the causes of loss of balance,dizziness,or the
inability to coordinate movement or activities.
Purpose
Tests of balance and coordination,and the examina-
tion of the organs and systems that influence balance and
coordination, can help to identify causes of dizziness,
fainting,falling,or incoordination.

--- Chunk 2562 ---
Precautions
Tests for balance and coordination should be con-
ducted in a safe and controlled area where patients will
not experience injury if they become dizzy or fall.
Description
Assessment of balance and coordination can include with vision may,in themselves,contribute to balance and
discussion of the patient’s medical history and a com- coordination disturbances,or may indicate more serious
plete physical examinationincluding evaluation of the problems of the nervous system or brain function. Hear-
heart,head,eyes,and ears. A slow pulse or heart rate,or ing loss, fluid in the inner ear, or ear infection might
very low blood pressure may indicate a circulatory sys- indicate the cause of balance and coordination problems.
tem problem,which can cause dizziness or fainting.

--- Chunk 2563 ---
Dur-
Various physical tests may also be used. A patient
ing the examination,the patient may be asked to rotate
may be asked to walk a straight line,stand on one foot,
the head from side to side while sitting up or while lying
or touch a finger to the nose to help assess balance. The
down with the head and neck extended over the edge of
patient may be asked to squeeze or push against the
the examination table. If these tests produce dizziness or
doctor’s hands, to squat down, to bend over, stand on
a rapid twitching of the eyeballs (nystagmus), the
tiptoes or stand on their heels. Important aspects of
patient may have a disorder of the inner ear, which is
these tests include holding positions for a certain num-
responsible for maintaining balance.

--- Chunk 2564 ---

The bacteria,Bartonella bacilliformis,was isolated
by Alberto Barton in 1909,but wasn’t identified as the
