--- Chunk 2639 ---
The Bartonella genus
includes at least 11 bacteria species,four of which cause
Bartonellosis human diseases, including cat-scratch disease and
bacillary angiomatosis. However,bartonellosis refers
Definition
exclusively to the disease caused by B. bacilliformis. The
Bartonellosis is an infectious bacterial disease with disease is limited to a small area of the Andes Mountains
an acute form (which has a sudden onset and short in western South America; nearly all cases have been in
course) and a chronic form (which has more gradual Peru,Colombia,and Ecuador. A large outbreak involving
onset and longer duration). The disease is transmitted by thousands of people occurred in 1940–41,but bartonel-
sandflies and occurs in western South America. Charac- losis has since occurred sporadically.

anemia) and fever, the potentially fatal acute form is credited with managing the disease.
called Oroya fever or Carrion’s disease. The chronic
form is identified by painful skin lesions.

cigarette burns; scald marks; bite marks; black eyes;
Subdural hematoma—Bleeding over the brain.

--- Chunk 2647 ---

Battered child syndrome is most often diagnosed by
an emergency room physician or pediatrician, or by abused as children; absence of visible parental love or
teachers or social workers. Physical examinationwill concern for the child; child’s hygiene neglected.

Medical treatment for battered child syndrome will
vary according to the type of injury incurred. Counseling Mary Jane Tenerelli
and the implementation of an intervention plan for the
child’s parents or guardians is necessary.

--- Chunk 2649 ---
The child abuser Becker muscular dystrophy see Muscular
may be incarcerated, and/or the abused child removed dystrophy
from the home to prevent further harm. Reporting child
abuse to authorities is mandatory for doctors, teachers,
and childcare workers in most states as a way to prevent
continued abuse. Both physical and psychological therapy
are often recommended as treatment for the abused child.

--- صفحة 471 ---
Bedsores are not cancerous or contagious. They are
most likely to occur in people who must use wheelchairs
or who are confined to bed.

--- Chunk 2672 ---
In 1992,the federal Agency
for Health Care Policy and Research reported that bed-
sores afflict:
•10% of hospital patients
•25% of nursing home residents
•60% of quadriplegics
The Agency also noted that 65% of elderly people
hospitalized with broken hips develop bedsores and that
doctors fees for treatment of bedsores amounted to
$2,900 per person.
Bedsores are most apt to develop on the:
•ankles
•back of the head
Slight rubbing or friction against the skin can cause
•heels minor pressure ulcers. They can also develop when a
•hips patient stretches or bends blood vessels by slipping into a
different position in a bed or chair.

--- Chunk 2673 ---
•knees
Urine,feces,or other moisture increases the risk of
•lower back
skin infection,and people who are unable to move or rec-
•shoulder blades ognize internal cues to shift position have a greater than
•spine average risk of developing bedsores.
People over the age of 60 are more likely than younger Other risk factors include:
people to develop bedsores.

--- Chunk 2674 ---
Risk is also increased by:
•malnutrition
•atherosclerosis (hardening of arteries)
•anemia (lack of red blood cells)
•diabetes or other conditions that make skin more sus-
•diuse atrophy (muscle loss or weakness from lack of
ceptible to infection
use)
•diminished sensation or lack of feeling
•infection
•heart problems
•incontinence (inability to control bladder or bowel
Diagnosis
movements)
Physical examination,medical history,and patient
•malnutrition
and caregiver observations are the basis of diagnosis.
•obesity
Special attention must be paid to physical or mental
•paralysis or immobility problems, like incontinence or confusion, that could
complicate a patient’s recovery.

--- Chunk 2675 ---
•poor circulation
Bedsores usually follow six stages:
•prolonged bed rest,especially in unsanitary conditions
or with wet or wrinkled sheets •redness of skin
•spinal cord injury •redness,swelling,and possible peeling of outer layer of
skin
Causes and symptoms •dead skin,draining wound,and exposed layer of fat
Bedsores most often develop when constant pressure •tissue deaththrough skin and fat,to muscle
pinches tiny blood vessels that deliver oxygen and nutri-
•inner fat and muscle death
ents to the skin. When skin is deprived of oxygen and
nutrients for as little as an hour,areas of tissue can die •destruction of bone,bone,infection,fracture,and blood
and bedsores can form. infection

is most prevalent in Japan, the Middle East, and in the
Resources Mediterranean region. There is a wider prevalence
among males than females in a ratio of two to one.

--- Chunk 2698 ---
Why the facial nerve becomes inflamed in Bell’s
palsy is a matter of some debate,and medical researchers
Description

Bell’s palsy has been described as a diagnosis of ported evidence implicates the herpes simplex virus

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 461
Bell’s
palsy
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 461
--- صفحة 476 ---
tion—the usual mode of examination is to rule out other
disorders until only Bell’s palsy is left. Disorders that
need to be excluded include demyelinating disease (e.g.,
multiple sclerosis), stroke, tumors, bacterial or viral
infection,and bone fracture.

--- Chunk 2699 ---
During the physical examination,the afflicted indi-
vidual is asked about recent illnesses,accidents,infec-
tions, and any other symptoms. A visual exam of the
ears,throat,and sinus is done,and hearing is tested. The
extent of the symptoms is assessed by grading the sym-
metry of the face at rest and during voluntary move-
ments, such as wrinkling the forehead, puckering the
lips, and closing the affected eye. Involuntary move-
ments are assessed in combination with the voluntary
movements. Neurologic exam is done to rule out
involvement of other parts of the nervous system except
for the facial muscles,which would exclude the diagno-
sis of Bell’s palsy.
In response to the individual’s medical history,
blood tests and possibly a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
analysis are ordered.

--- Chunk 2700 ---
The results of these tests help
determine the presence of a bacterial or viral infection or
an inflammatory disease. Electrophysiological tests,in
which a muscle or nerve is artificially stimulated,may be
used to assess the condition of facial muscles and the
facial nerve. Common tests include electromyography,
which measures voluntary muscle movement,and nerve
conduction velocity, which determines the extent of
nerve degeneration. Radiological tests may also be
blisters. HSV infection has been discovered in up to 70%
included,such as an x ray,as well as imaging tests,such
of Bell’s palsy cases. Most people harbor this virus,
as magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) and computed
although they may not exhibit symptoms.
tomography.

A routine urinalysis will not detect Bence Jones
proteins. There are several methods used by laboratories
to detect and measure these proteins. The classic Bence
Jones reaction involves heating urine to 140°F (60°C). At
Bender-Gestalt test
this temperature,the Bence Jones proteins will clump.
The clumping disappears if the urine is further heated to
Definition
boiling and reappears when the urine is cooled. Other
clumping procedures using salts,acids,and other chemi- The Bender Visual Motor Gestalt test (or Bender-

Paula Anne Ford-Martin The recommended dosage depends on the type of
benzodiazepine,its strength,and the condition for which
Bends see Decompression sickness it is being taken. Doses may be different for different
people. Check with the physician who prescribed the
Benign see Uterine fibroids
drug or the pharmacist who filled the prescription for the
Benign prostatic hyperplasia see Enlarged correct dosage.
prostate
Always take benzodiazepines exactly as directed.
Benign prostatic hypertrophy see Enlarged Never take larger or more frequent doses,and do not take
the drug for longer than directed. If the medicine does not
prostate
seem to be working,check with the physician who pre-
Benzocaine see Antiseptics scribed it.

--- Chunk 2722 ---
Do not increase the dose or stop taking the
medicine unless the physician says to do so.Stopping the
drug suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms, espe-
cially if it has been taken in large doses or over a long
period. People who are taking the medicine for seizure
Benzodiazepines
disorders may have seizures if they stop taking it sudden-
ly. If it is necessary to stop taking the medicine, check
Definition
with a physician for directions on how to stop. The physi-
Benzodiazepines are medicines that help relieve ner- cian may recommend tapering down gradually to reduce
vousness, tension, and other symptoms by slowing the the chance of withdrawal symptoms or other problems.
central nervous system.

lungs become inflamed and narrowed. sweating, dizziness, chest pain, and extreme fear
often accompany the attacks.

lungs. Phobia—An intense, abnormal, or illogical fear of
something specific, such as heights or open spaces.
Central nervous system—The brain, spinal cord
and the nerves throughout the body. Porphyria—A disorder in which porphyrins build
up in the blood and urine.

condition. Chronic conditions often develop gradu- Porphyrin—A type of pigment found in living

renal hematuric/proteinuric syndrome Causes and symptoms
Thiamine is one of the B vitamins and plays an
important role in energy metabolism and tissue building.

--- Chunk 2741 ---
It combines with phosphate to form the coenzyme thi-
amine pyrophosphate (TPP),which is essential in reac-
Beriberi tions that produce energy from glucose or that convert
glucose to fat for storage in the tissues. When there is not
Definition enough thiamine in the diet,these basic energy functions
are disturbed,leading to problems throughout the body.
Beriberi is a disease caused by a deficiency of thi-
amine (vitamin B) that affects many systems of the Special situations, such as an over-active metabo-
1
body,including the muscles,heart,nerves,and digestive lism, prolonged fever, pregnancy, and breastfeeding,
system.

is primarily seen in people with chronic alcoholism. including thiamine. Other persons at risk are patients
with kidney failure on dialysis and those with severe
digestive problems who are unable to absorb nutrients.

intake of calories. The current recommended dietary
allowances (RDA) are 0.5 mg for every 1,000 calories,

Nancy J. Nordenson
The blood test requires 5 mL of blood. A healthcare
worker ties a tourniquet on the person’s upper arm,
locates a vein in the inner elbow region, and inserts a
needle into that vein.

through the needle into an attached tube. Collection of Beta blockers
the sample takes only a few minutes.

--- صفحة 490 ---
Also, taking this medicine may hide a fast heartbeat,

--- Chunk 2780 ---
Effects of these drugs may be greater in people with
kidney or liver disease because the medicine is cleared
from the body more slowly.
Beta blockers may also make the following medical
conditions worse:
•Heart or blood vessel disease
•Unusually slow heartbeat (bradycardia)
•Myasthenia gravis (chronic disease causing muscle
weakness and possibly paralysis)
•Psoriasis (itchy,scaly,red patches of skin)
•Depression (now,or in the past).
Before using beta blockers,people with any of the
medical problems listed in this section should make sure
their physicians are aware of their conditions.
USE OF CERTAIN MEDICINES. Taking beta blockers
with certain other drugs may affect the way the drugs
work or may increase the chance of side effects.

--- Chunk 2781 ---

medicine.

Prognosis
Prognosis depends on the stage and resectability of
the tumor. If the patient cannot undergo surgical resec- Biliary atresia
tion, then the survival rate is commonly less than one
year. If the tumor is resected,the survival rate improves, Definition
with 20% of these patients surviving past five years.
Biliary atresia is the failure of a fetus to develop an
adequate pathway for bile to drain from the liver to the

KEY TERMS
Duodenum—The first part of the small intestine,
beginning at the outlet of the stomach.
Hemoglobin—The red, iron-containing chemical
in the blood that carries oxygen to the tissues.
Jaundice—The yellow color taken on by a patient
whose liver is unable to excrete bilirubin. A normal
condition in the first week of life due to the infant’s
delayed ability to process certain waste products.

--- Chunk 2804 ---
Kernicterus—A potentially lethal disease of new-
borns caused by excessive accumulation of the
bile pigment bilirubin.

--- Chunk 2820 ---
In 1961,Neal Miller,an experimental psychologist,
Paula Anne Ford-Martin suggested that autonomic nervous system responses (for
482 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
kcabdeefoiB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 482
--- صفحة 497 ---
instance, heart rate, blood pressure, gastrointestinal
activity,regional blood flow) could be under voluntary
control. As a result of his experiments,he showed that
such autonomic processes were controllable. This work
led to the creation of biofeedback therapy. Willer’s work
was expanded by other researchers. Thereafter,research
performed in the 1970s by UCLA researcher Dr. Barry
Sterman established that both cats and monkeys could be
trained to control their brain wave patterns.

--- Chunk 2821 ---
Sterman then
used his research techniques on human patients with
epilepsy,where he was able to reduce seizures by 60%
with the use of biofeedback techniques. Throughout the
1970s,other researchers published reports of their use of
biofeedback in the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias,
headaches, Raynaud’s syndrome, and excess stomach
acid,and as a tool for teaching deep relaxation. Since the
early work of Miller and Sterman, biofeedback has
developed into a front-line behavioral treatment for an
even wider range of disorders and symptoms.
During biofeedback,special sensors are placed on
the body.

--- Chunk 2822 ---
These sensors measure the bodily function that
is causing the patient problem symptoms,such as heart
rate, blood pressure, muscle tension (EMG or elec-
tromyographic feedback), brain waves (EEC or elec- quency. Delta,the slowest frequency wave,is the brain
troencophalographic feedback), respiration, and body wave pattern associated with sleep. Beta waves,which
temperature (thermal feedback),and translates the infor- occur in a normal,waking state,can range from 12-35
mation into a visual and/or audible readout, such as a Hz. Problems begin to develop when beta wave averages
paper tracing,a light display,or a series of beeps. fall in the low end (underarousal) or the high end (over-
arousal) of that spectrum.

--- Chunk 2823 ---

disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, or excessive

brain wave patterns,body temperature,and other bodily

functions. This is achieved through relaxation exercises,

Raynaud’s syndrome—A vascular, or circulatory
system, disorder which is characterized by abnor-
mally cold hands and feet. This chilling effect is
caused by constriction of the blood vessels in the Bipolar disorder
extremities, and occurs when the hands and feet
are exposed to cold weather. Emotional stress can Definition
also trigger the cold symptoms.

Birth trauma and uterine factors–1%
Maternal metabolic factors–1%
Maternal infection–2%
Drugs, chemicals, radiation–2%
Cytogenetic diseases–4%
Hereditary diseases–20%
Unknown causes–70%
The specific cause of many birth defects is unknown,but several factors associated with pregnancy and delivery can
increase the risk of birth defects.These factors include exposure to teratogens,drugs and other chemicals,exposure to radi-
ation,and infections present in the womb.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)
--- صفحة 506 ---
not process sugar,can also cause birth defects in the child.
An abnormal amount of amniotic fluid may indicate or
cause birth defects.

--- Chunk 2878 ---
Amniotic fluid is the liquid that sur-
rounds and protects the unborn child in the uterus. Too lit-
tle of this fluid can interfere with lung or limb develop-
ment. Too much amniotic fluid can accumulate if the
fetus has a disorder that interferes with swallowing.
Diagnosis
If there is a family history of birth defects or if the
mother is over 35 years old,then screening tests can be
done during pregnancy to gain information about the
health of the baby.
•Alpha-fetoprotein test. This is a simple blood test that
measure the level of a substance called alpha-fetopro-
tein that is associated with some major birth defects. An
abnormally high or low level may indicate the need for
further testing.
•Ultrasound.

--- Chunk 2879 ---
The use of sound waves to examine the
shape,function,and age of the fetus is a common proce-
dure. It can also detect many malformations, such as
spina bifida,limb defects,and heart and kidney problems.
•Amniocentesis. This test is usually done between the

Angiomas and vascular malformations are not diffi-

--- Chunk 2895 ---
The doctor may empty the
mark of blood by gentle pressure. Biopsies or specialized
x rays or scans of the abnormal vessels and their sur-
rounding areas may be performed. Patients with port-
wine stains near the eye may require skull x rays,com-
puted tomography scans, and vision and central ner-
vous system tests. Most insurance plans pay for diagno-
sis and treatment of these conditions.
Treatment
Treatment choices for skin angiomas and vascular
malformations depend on their type,location,and severity,
and whether they cause symptoms,pain,or disfigurement.
Watchful waiting
No treatment is given,but the mark is regularly exam- out damaging normal skin. Two types of lasers are used:
ined.

HUMANS. Bites from mammals other than dogs and
cats are uncommon,with one exception—human bites.
There are approximately 70,000 human bites each year
in the United States.

--- Chunk 2909 ---
Because the human mouth contains
a multitude of potentially harmful microorganisms,
Bites and stings human bites are more infectious than those of most other
animals.
Definition
Humans can be injured by the bites or stings of
Arthropods
many kinds of animals, including mammals such as
dogs,cats,and fellow humans; arthropods such as spi- Arthropods are invertebrates belonging to the phy-
ders,bees,and wasps; snakes; and marine animals such lum Arthropoda,which includes insects,arachnids,crus-
as jellyfish and stingrays. taceans, and other subgroups. There are more than
700,000 species in all. The list of arthropods that bite or
sting humans is extensive and includes lice, bedbugs,
Description
fleas,mosquitoes,black flies,ants,chiggers,ticks,cen-
Mammals tipedes,scorpions,and other species.

during a single episode. Infected bites usually cause pain, excessive sweating, nausea, vomiting, headaches, and

--- صفحة 513 ---
A brown spider’s bite can lead to necrotic arachni-
dism,in which the tissue in an area of up to several inch-
es around the bite becomes necrotic (dies),producing an
open sore that can take months or years to disappear. In
most cases, however, the bite simply produces a hard,
painful, itchy, and discolored area that heals without
treatment in 2-3 days. The bite may also be accompanied
by a fever,chills,edema(an accumulation of excess tis-
sue fluid),nausea and vomiting,dizziness,muscle and
joint pain,and a rash.
BEES AND WASPS. The familiar symptoms of bee
and wasp stings include pain,redness,swelling,and itch-
iness in the area of the sting.

--- Chunk 2920 ---
Multiple stings can have
much more severe consequences,such as anaphylaxis,a
life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs in hypersen-
sitive persons.
sive sweating, and other symptoms. In rare instances,
cardiorespiratory failure may also occur.

An insect bite caused this person’s lower lip to swell.(Cus-

--- Chunk 2925 ---

--- صفحة 514 ---
applying pressure to the injured area with a clean towel
to stop the bleeding. The next step is to apply antibiotic
ointment and a sterile bandage to the wound. To reduce
swelling and fend off infection,ice should be applied and
the injured area kept elevated above the level of the heart.
The wound should be cleaned and covered with ointment
twice a day until it heals.
Any dog bite that does not stop bleeding after 15
minutes of pressure must be seen by a medical profes-
sional. The same is true for bites that are deep or gaping;
for bites to the head, hands, or feet; and for bites that
may have broken a bone, damaged nerves, or caused a
major injury of another kind. Bite victims must also
watch for infection.

--- Chunk 2926 ---
A fever is one sign of infection,as
are redness,swelling,warmth,increased tenderness,and
pus at the wound site. Diabetics, people with AIDS or
cancer,individuals who have not had a tetanus shot in
five years,and anyone else who has a medical problem

medical treatment no matter how minor the bite appears.

--- Chunk 2950 ---
The risk is much lower today,
however; fewer than 10% of coal miners have any x
ray evidence of coal dust deposits. When there is such
Black lung disease evidence, it often shows up as only small black spots
less than 0.4 in (1 cm). in diameter, and may have
Definition been caused by smoking rather than coal dust. This
condition is called “simple CWP”and does not lead to
Black lung disease is the common name for coal
symptoms or disability.
workers’ pneumoconiosis (CWP) or anthracosis, a
lung disease of older workers in the coal industry,
caused by inhalation, over many years, of small Causes and symptoms
amounts of coal dust.

tually, this build-up causes thickening and scarring,

Diagnosis
The diagnosis of bladder stones is usually made after a

Prognosis
Most bladder stones can be,and are,passed out of
the body in the urine without any permanent damage to
the bladder or the rest of the urinary tract. However,most
Bladder training
bladder stones arise from an underlying medical condi-
tion. Therefore,if this medical condition is not corrected
Definition
approximately half of all patients will experience a recur-
rence of bladder stones within five years. Bladder training is a behavioral modification treat-
ment technique for urinary incontinencethat involves
placing a patient on a toileting schedule.

--- Chunk 2992 ---
Blastomycosis is also called Gilchrist’s dis-
512 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
sisocymotsalB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 512
--- صفحة 527 ---
ease,Chicago disease,or North American blastomycosis.
Another South and Central American disease,paracoc-
cidioidomycosis,is sometimes called South American
blastomycosis,but despite the similar name,this disease
is substantially different from North American blastomy-
cosis. Canine blastomycosis,a common dog disease,is
caused by the same fungus that infects humans. Howev-
er,people do not get this disease from their dogs except
only very rarely through dog bites.
Blastomycosis is a rare disease infecting only about
4 in every 100,000 people.

--- Chunk 2993 ---
It is at least six times more
common in men than in women and tends to more often
infect children and individuals in the 30–50 year old age
group. People who have diabetes mellitus or who are
taking drugs that suppress the immune system (immuno-
compromised) are more likely to develop blastomycosis.
Although people with AIDS can get blastomycosis

It indicates how well platelets

Purpose
Systemic—Not localized to a single area of the body
but, instead, involving one or more body systems. Bleeding time is used most often to detect qualitative
defects of platelets,such as Von Willebrand’s disease. The
test helps identify people who have defects in their
platelet function. This is the ability of blood to clot fol-
(Tabebuia impetiginosa),and garlic may also be applied
lowing a wound or trauma. Normally,platelets interact
directly to the infected skin.
with the walls of blood vessels to cause a blood clot.

--- Chunk 3014 ---
Treatment
Symptoms of bleeding varices include The objective during treatment of bleeding varices is
to stop and/or prevent bleeding and to restore/maintain
•vomiting blood,sometimes in massive amounts
normal blood circulation throughout the body. Patients
•black,tarry stools
with severe bleeding should be treated in intensive care
•decreased urine output since uncontrolled bleeding can lead to death.

--- Chunk 3018 ---
Johnson
Some alternative treatments are aimed at preventing
Blepharitis see Eyelid disorders
the cirrhosis of the liver that often causes bleeding varices
and most are effective. However, once a patient has
reached the bleeding varice stage,standard intervention to
stop the bleeding is required or the patient may die.
Blepharoplasty
Prognosis
Definition
Bleeding varices represent one of the most feared
complications of portal hypertension. They contribute to Blepharoplasty is a cosmetic surgical procedure that
the estimated 32,000 deaths per year attributed to cirrho- removes fat deposits,excess tissue,or muscle from the
sis. Half or more of patients who survive episodes of eyelids to improve the appearance of the eyes.

--- Chunk 3019 ---
bleeding varices are at risk of renewed esophageal bleed-
ing during the first one to two years. The risk of recur- Purpose
rence can be lowered by endoscopic and drug treatment.
The primary use of blepharoplasty is for improving
Prognosis is usually more related to the underlying liver
the cosmetic appearance of the eyes. In some older
disease. Approximately 30 to 50 percent of people with
patients,however,sagging and excess skin surrounding
bleeding varices will die from this condition within the
the eyes can be so extensive that it limits the range of
six weeks of the first bleeding episode.
vision. In those cases,blepharoplasty serves a more func-
tional purpose.

--- Chunk 3020 ---
Prevention
The best way to possibly prevent the development or
Precautions
recurrence of bleeding varices is to eliminate the risk fac-
tors for cirrhosis of the liver. The most common cause of Before performing blepharoplasty,the surgeon will
cirrhosis is prolonged alcohol abuse, and alcohol con- assess whether the patient is a good candidate for the
GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 517
Blepharoplasty
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 517
--- صفحة 532 ---
treatment. A good medical history is important. The sur-
geon will want to know about any history of thyroid dis-
ease, hypertension, or eye problems, which may
increase the risk of complications.

--- Chunk 3021 ---
Description
Blepharoplasty can be performed on the upper or
lower eyelid; it can involve the removal of excess skin
and fat deposits and the tightening of selected muscles
surrounding the eyelids. The goal is to provide a more
youthful appearance.
The surgeon will begin by deciding whether excess
skin,fat deposits,or muscle looseness are at fault. While
the patient is sitting upright,the surgeon will mark on the
skin where incisions will be made. Care will be taken to
hide the incision lines in the natural skin folds above and
below the eye. The patient then receives injections of a
local anesthetic to numb the pain. Many surgeons also give
the patient a sedative intravenously during the procedure.

--- Chunk 3022 ---
After a small,crescent-shaped section of eyelid skin
is removed, the surgeon will work to tease out small
pockets of fat that have collected in the lids. If muscle
looseness is also a problem,the surgeon may trim tissue
or add a stitch to pull it tighter. Then the incision is
closed with stitches.
In some patients,fat deposits in the lower eyelid may
be the only or primary problem. Such patients may be
good candidates for transconjunctival blepharoplasty. In
this procedure the surgeon makes no incision on the sur-
face of the eyelid,but instead enters from behind to tease
out the fat deposits from a small incision. The advantage
of this procedure is that there is no visible scar.

--- Chunk 3023 ---
Preparation
Prior to surgery,patients meet with their surgeon to
discuss the procedure, clarify the results that can be
achieved,and discuss the potential problems that might
occur. Having realistic expectations is important in any
cosmetic procedure. Patients will learn,for example,that
although blepharoplasty can improve the appearance of
the eyelid, other procedures, such as a chemical peel,
will be necessary to reduce the appearance of wrinkles
around the eye. Some surgeons prescribe vitamin C and
vitamin K for 10 days prior to surgery in the belief that
this helps the healing process. Patients are also told to
stop smoking in the weeks before and after the proce-
dure,and to refrain from alcohol and aspirin.

--- Chunk 3024 ---
Aftercare
An antibiotic ointment is applied to the line of stitch-
es for several days after surgery. Patients also take an

antibiotic several times a day to prevent infection. Ice-
cold compresses are applied to the eyes continuously for KEY TERMS
the first day following surgery,and several times a day for
the next week or so,to reduce swelling.

return to their usual activities within a week to 10 days. Retrobulbar hematoma—A rare complication of
blepharoplasty, in which a pocket of blood forms
behind the eyeball.

Abnormal results
Richard H. Camer
As noted,if too much excess skin is removed from
the upper eyelid,the patient may be unable to close his
Blindness see Visual impairment
eyes completely; another surgery to correct the defect
may be required. Similarly, too much skin can be
removed from the lower eyelid,allowing too much of the
white of the eye (the sclera) to show. In extreme cases,
the lower lid may be pulled down too far,revealing the
underlying tissue. Called an ectropion, this, too, may Blood-viscosity reducing drugs
require a second,corrective surgery.

--- صفحة 535 ---
Blood count
Definition
One of the most commonly ordered clinical labora-
tory tests, a blood count, also called a complete blood
count (CBC),is a basic evaluation of the cells (red blood
cells,white blood cells,and platelets) suspended in the
liquid part of the blood (plasma). It involves determining
the numbers,concentrations,and conditions of the differ-
ent types of blood cells.
Purpose
The CBC is a useful screening and diagnostic test
that is often done as part of a routine physical examina-
tion. It can provide valuable information about the blood
and blood-forming tissues (especially the bone marrow),
as well as other body systems.

--- Chunk 3037 ---
Abnormal results can indi-
cate the presence of a variety of conditions—including
anemias,leukemias,and infections—sometimes before
the patient experiences symptoms of the disease.
Description
The red blood cell (RBC) count determines the total
A complete blood count is actually a series of tests number of red cells (erythrocytes) in a sample of blood.
in which the numbers of red blood cells, white blood The red cells, the most numerous of the cellular ele-
cells,and platelets in a given volume of blood are count- ments,carry oxygen from the lungs to the body’s tissues.
ed. The CBC also measures the hemoglobin content and Hemoglobin (Hgb) is the protein-iron compound in the
the packed cell volume (hematocrit) of the red blood red blood cells that enables them to transport oxygen.

--- Chunk 3038 ---

--- صفحة 541 ---
Blood gas analysis
Definition
Blood gas analysis, also called arterial blood gas
(ABG) analysis,is a test which measures the amounts of
oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood,as well as the
acidity (pH) of the blood.
Purpose
An ABG analysis evaluates how effectively the
lungs are delivering oxygen to the blood and how effi-
ciently they are eliminating carbon dioxide from it.

--- Chunk 3075 ---
The
test also indicates how well the lungs and kidneys are
interacting to maintain normal blood pH (acid-base bal-
ance). Blood gas studies are usually done to assess respi-
ratory disease and other conditions that may affect the
lungs,and to manage patients receiving oxygen therapy
(respiratory therapy). In addition,the acid-base compo-
nent of the test provides information on kidney function.
Description
Blood gas analysis is performed on blood from an
artery. It measures the partial pressures of oxygen and
carbon dioxide in the blood,as well as oxygen content,
oxygen saturation,bicarbonate content,and blood pH.
Oxygen in the lungs is carried to the tissues through
the bloodstream,but only a small amount of this oxygen
can actually dissolve in arterial blood.

--- Chunk 3076 ---
How much dis-
solves depends on the partial pressure of the oxygen (the
pressure that the gas exerts on the walls of the arteries).
Therefore,testing the partial pressure of oxygen is actu-
ally measuring how much oxygen the lungs are deliver- the pH at a level where the body’s cellular functions are
ing to the blood. Carbon dioxide is released into the most efficient. The lungs and kidneys both participate in
blood as a by-product of cell metabolism. The partial maintaining the carbonic acid-bicarbonate balance. The
carbon dioxide pressure indicates how well the lungs are lungs control the carbonic acid level and the kidneys reg-
eliminating this carbon dioxide. ulate the bicarbonate. If either organ is not functioning
properly,an acid-base imbalance can result.

--- Chunk 3077 ---
Determina-
The remainder of oxygen that is not dissolved in the
tion of bicarbonate and pH levels,then,aids in diagnos-
blood combines with hemoglobin,a protein—iron com-
ing the cause of abnormal blood gas values.
pound found in the red blood cells. The oxygen content
measurement in an ABG analysis indicates how much
oxygen is combined with the hemoglobin. A related The procedure
value is the oxygen saturation, which compares the

the total amount of oxygen that the hemoglobin is capa-
from an arterial line already in place. If a puncture is need-
ble of combining with.

Preparation
Carol A. Turkington
There are no special preparations. Patients have no
restrictions on drinking or eating before the test.

--- Chunk 3081 ---

Aftercare
After the blood has been taken,the technician or the
patient applies pressure to the puncture site for 10–15 Blood sugar tests
minutes to stop the bleeding,and then places a dressing
over the puncture.The patient should rest quietly while Definition
applying the pressure to the puncture site.

--- Chunk 3082 ---
Health care
Blood sugar tests include several different tests that
workers will observe the patient for signs of bleeding or
measure the amount of sugar (glucose) in a person’s
circulation problems
blood. These tests are done either on an empty stomach,
or after consuming a meal or premeasured glucose drink.
Risks Blood sugar tests are done primarily to diagnose and
evaluate a person with diabetes mellitus.
Risks are very low when the test is done correctly.
Risks include bleeding or bruising at the site,or delayed
bleeding from the site. Very rarely,there may be a prob- Purpose
lem with circulation in the puncture area.
The body uses sugar,also called glucose,to supply
the energy it needs to function. People get sugar from
Normal results their diet and from their body tissues.

--- Chunk 3083 ---
Insulin is made by
the pancreas and affects the outer membrane of cells,

making it easy for glucose to move from the blood into

Definition
can be anything that causes the body to launch an attack,
Blood typing is a laboratory test done to determine a known as an immune response, against it. The attack

bodies against its own antigens, only against antigens
that are foreign to it.
Purpose

Blood urea nitrogen test KEY TERMS
Definition
Urea—A compound containing nitrogen that
The blood urea nitrogen (BUN) test measures the occurs in the urine and other body fluids as a
level of urea nitrogen in a sample of the patient’s blood.

--- Chunk 3121 ---
result of protein metabolism.
Urea is a substance that is formed in the liver when the
body breaks down protein. Urea then circulates in the
blood in the form of urea nitrogen. In healthy people,
most urea nitrogen is filtered out by the kidneys and
Normal results
leaves the body in the urine. If the patient’s kidneys are
not functioning properly or if the body is using large Normal BUN levels are 5-18 mg/dL for children; 7-
amounts of protein,the BUN level will rise. If the patient 18 mg/dL for adults; and 8-20 mg/dL in the elderly.
has severe liver disease,the BUN will drop.
Abnormal results
Purpose
BUN levels can be too low as well as too high.
The BUN level may be checked in order to assess or
monitor:
Abnormally low BUN
•the presence or progression of kidney or liver disease.

--- Chunk 3122 ---
Low levels of BUN may indicate overhydration,
•blockage of urine flow.
malnutrition,celiac disease[a disease characterized by
•mental confusion. Patients with kidney failure are the inability ot tolerate foods containing wheat protein
sometimes disoriented and confused. (gluten)], liver damage or disease, or use of corticos-
•abnormal loss of water from the body (dehydration). teroids. Low BUN may also occur in early pregnancy.
•recovery from severe burns. The body uses larger than
normal amounts of protein following serious burns.

--- Chunk 3123 ---
Abnormally high BUN
High levels of BUN may indicate kidney disease or
Description
failure; blockage of the urinary tract by a kidney stone or
The BUN test is performed on a sample of the tumor; a heart attackor congestive heart failure; dehy-
patient’s blood, withdrawn from a vein into a vacuum dration; fever; shock; or bleeding in the digestive tract.
tube. The procedure, which is called a venipuncture, High BUN levels can sometimes occur during late preg-
takes about five minutes. nancy or result from eating large amounts of protein-rich
foods. A BUN level higher than 100 mg/dL points to
severe kidney damage.
Preparation
The doctor should check to make sure that the
patient is not taking any medications that can affect BUN Resources
results.

--- Chunk 3124 ---
These drugs include the antibiotics chloram- BOOKS
phenicol, streptomycin, amphotericin B, methicillin, Everything You Need to Know About Medical Tests.Ed.
gentamicin, tobramycin, and kanamycin, as well as Michael Shaw,et al. Springhouse,PA:Springhouse Cor-
diureticsand corticosteroids. poration,1996.
A Manual of Laboratory and Diagnostic Tests.5th ed. Ed.
The patient should be advised not to eat large
Francis Fishback. Philadelphia:Lippincott,1996.
amounts of meat the day before the test.

--- صفحة 550 ---
Boils
Definition
Boils and carbuncles are bacterial infections of hair
follicles and surrounding skin that form pustules (small
blister-like swellings containing pus) around the follicle.
Boils are sometimes called furuncles. A carbuncle is
formed when several furuncles merge to form a single
deep abscesswith several heads or drainage points.

--- Chunk 3126 ---
Description
Boils and carbuncles are firm reddish swellings about
Boils often occur from a bacterial infection in a hair follicle
0.2-0.4 in (5-10 mm) across that are slightly raised above
or skin gland.(Custom Medical Stock Photo.Reproduced by
the skin surface. They are sore to the touch. A boil usually
permission.)
has a visible central core of pus; a carbuncle is larger and
has several visible heads. Boils occur most commonly on
painful to touch. As the boil matures,it forms a yellowish
the face,back of the neck,buttocks,upper legs and groin
head or point. It may either continue to swell until the
area,armpits,and upper torso.

--- Chunk 3127 ---

536 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
slioB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 536
--- صفحة 551 ---
boils and carbuncles are not difficult to distinguish from
other skin disorders.
S. aureuscan easily be cultured in the laboratory if
the doctor needs to rule out inclusion cysts or deep fun-
gal infections that gardeners sometimes get. The doctor
can make a culture from pus taken from the boil or car-
buncle to confirm the diagnosis of a staphylococcal
infection.

--- Chunk 3132 ---
He or she can also culture the patient’s nasal
discharge to test for the presence of a S. aureuscolony.
Treatment
Patient and family education
Patient education is an important part of the treatment
of boils and carbuncles. Patients need to be warned against
picking at or squeezing boils because of the danger of
spreading the infection into other parts of the skin or
bloodstream. It is especially important to avoid squeezing Surgical treatment
boils around the mouth or nose because infections in these
Boils and carbuncles that are very large,or that are
areas can be carried to the brain. Patients should also be
not draining,may be opened with a sterile needle or sur-
advised about keeping the skin clean,washing their hands
gical knife to allow the pus to drain.

--- Chunk 3133 ---
The doctor will usu-
carefully before and after touching the boil or carbuncle,
ally give the patient a local anesthetic if a knife is used;
avoiding the use of greasy cosmetics or creams,and keep-
surgical treatment of boils is painful and usually leaves
ing their towels and washcloths separate from those of
noticeable scars.
other family members. Some doctors may recommend an
antiseptic soap or gel for washing the infected areas.
Alternative treatment
If the patient has had several episodes of furunculo-
sis, the doctor may examine family members or close Naturopathic therapy
contacts to see if they are carriers of S. aureus. In many
Naturopathic practitioners usually recommend
cases they also need treatment for boils or carbuncles.

--- Chunk 3134 ---
changes in the patient’s diet as well as applying herbal
Skin infections and reinfections involving small groups
poultices to the infected area. The addition of zinc sup-
or clusters of people are being reported more frequently
plements and vitamin A to the diet is reported to be
in the United States.
effective in treating boils. The application of a paste or
poultice containing goldenseal (Hydrastis canadensis)

Purpose
Bone densitometry see Bone density test
A bone density scan measures the strength of an
individual’s bones and determines the risk of fracture. An
observation of any osteoporosis present can be made.

--- Chunk 3148 ---
Description
Bone density test
To take a DEXA bone density scan,the patient lies on
a bed underneath the scanner,a curving plastic arm that
Definition
emits x rays. These low-dose x rays form a fan beam that
A bone density test,or scan,is designed to check for rotates around the patient. During the test, the scanner

bones lose calcium and other mineralsthat keep them strength and risk of fracture to that of other people in the
strong.

KEY TERMS
Calcium—A mineral that helps build bone.

--- Chunk 3152 ---
After
menopause, when women start making less of the
bone-protecting hormone estrogen, they may
need to increase their intake of calcium.
DEXA bone density scan—A bone density scan
that uses a rotating x-ray beam to measure the
strength of an individual’s bones and his or her
fracture risk.
Osteoporosis—A disease that occurs when the
bones lose the calcium and structure that keep
them strong. It often occurs after menopause
(around age 50) in women and in old age in men.
ranges from (cid:2)1 to (cid:2)2.5 they have low bone mass and
are at risk for osteoporosis. A T score below (cid:2)2.5 means
osteoporosis is already evident. These patients should
have a repeat bone density scan every year or two.

1 mean that a patient has a healthy bone mass. Scores
from 0 to (cid:2)1 mean that the patient has borderline bone
mass and should repeat the test in two to five years.

There are three ways in which a bone graft can help
repair a defect.

--- Chunk 3169 ---
The first is called osteogenesis,the for-
Raloxifene
mation of new bone by the cells contained within the
Raloxifene may affect blood clotting. Patients who graft. The second is osteoinduction,a chemical process
are taking other drugs that affect blood clotting,such as in which molecules contained within the graft (bone
warfarin (Coumadin),should check with their physicians morphogenetic proteins) convert the patient’s cells into
before using raloxifene. cells that are capable of forming bone. The third is osteo-
conduction,a physical effect by which the matrix of the
graft forms a scaffold on which cells in the recipient are

500 Washington,D.C. 20036-4603. <http://www.nof.org>. are also used instead of bone, including collagen (the

grafts,is also being studied.

--- Chunk 3171 ---
These resorbable grafts pro-
vide a structure for new bone to grow on; the grafts then
slowly dissolve,leaving only the new bone behind.
Bone grafting
To place the graft,the surgeon makes an incision in
Definition the skin over the bone defect and shapes the bone graft or
replacement material to fit into the defect. After the graft
Bone grafting is a surgical procedure by which new
is placed into the defect, it is held in place with pins,
bone or a replacement material is placed into spaces
plates,or screws. The incision is closed with stitches and
between or around broken bone (fractures) or holes in
a splint or cast is used to prevent movement of the bones
bone (defects) to aid in healing.
while healing.

patient,or fail to heal properly. Bone graft is also used to intensive care or private rooms); medication charges
help fusion between vertebrae, correct deformities, or ($200 to $400); and additional charges, including an
provide structural support for fractures of the spine. In assisting surgeon,treatment of complications,diagnostic
addition to fracture repair,bone graft is used to repair procedures (e.g.

Hydroxyapatite—A calcium phosphate complex
that is the primary mineral component of bone.
Most bone grafts are successful in helping the bone
defect to heal. The extent of recovery will depend on the Osteoblasts—Bone cells that build new bone tissue.
size of the defect and the condition of the bone sur-

White blood cells form Allogeneic transplants are more complicated

550 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
noitatnalpsnart
worram
enoB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 550
--- صفحة 565 ---
(HLA) that are on the surface of bone marrow cells. If
the donor and the recipient have very dissimilar antigens,
the recipient’s immune system regards the donor’s bone
marrow cells as invaders and launches a destructive
attack against them. Such an attack negates any benefits
offered by the transplant.
HLA matching
There are only five major HLA classes or types—
designated HLA–A,–B,–C,–D,and class III—but much
variation within the groupings.

--- Chunk 3206 ---
For example, HLA–A
from one individual may be similar to,but not the same
as, HLA–A in another individual; such a situation can
render a transplant from one to the other impossible.
HLA matching is more likely if the donor and recip-
ient are related,particularly if they are siblings; however,
an unrelated donor may be a potential match. Only in
rare cases is matching HLA types between two people
not an issue:if the recipient has an identical twin. Identi-
cal twins carry the same genes; therefore,the same anti-
gens. A bone marrow transplant between identical twins
is called a syngeneic transplant.
Peripheral blood stem cell transplants
A relatively recent development in stem cell trans-
plantation is the use of peripheral blood cells instead of
stem cells from bone marrow.

--- Chunk 3207 ---
Peripheral blood stem cells
(PBSCs) are obtained from circulating blood rather than
from bone marrow,but the amount of stem cells found in
being collected, several outpatient sessions are needed
the peripheral blood is much smaller than the amount of
and each session lasts approximately two–four hours.
stem cells found in the bone marrow. Peripheral blood
stem cells can be used in either autologous or allogeneic
The transplant procedure
transplants. The majority of PBSC transplants are autolo-
gous. However, recent clinical studies indicate that BONE MARROW TRANSPLANTATION. The bone mar-

GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:08 PM Page 551
In autologous bone marrow transplantation,stem cells are
collected from the patient.Once the patient has undergone
chemotherapy,the cells are replaced in the blood via an intra-
venous catheter.The cells return to the bone marrow and
begin producing healthy new cells.(Illustration by Argosy Inc.

These effects typically resolve quickly. Occasionally,
muscles that control the airway and breathing fail.
patients report flu-like symptoms but they are usually
self-limited.

months to recover from botulism,and severe cases can Bowel preparation is a procedure usually undertaken

Prognosis
Even with prompt treatment,brain abscess is fatal in
about 20% of cases. About half of those who survive Brain biopsy
have some residual neurological problems, including
Definition
seizures in many patients.

no evidence that head injurycauses brain tumors,but
researchers are trying to determine the relationship, if
any, between brain tumors and viruses, family history,
and long-term exposure to electromagnetic fields.
Symptoms do not usually appear until the tumor
grows large enough to displace,damage,or destroy deli-
cate brain tissue.

--- Chunk 3321 ---
When that happens, the patient may
experience:
•headaches that become increasingly painful and are
most painful when lying down
•nausea and vomiting or sudden attacks of vomiting not
accompanied by nausea
•seizures
•dizziness,loss of coordination or balance
•personality changes
•sudden loss of vision
•memory loss
•speech problems
•sensory changes
•mental impairment
•weakness or paralysison one side of the body
A doctor should be notified whenever a patient expe-
riences one or more of the symptoms.

Alternative treatment
Other treatments Alternative treatments have not been shown to cure
brain tumors and should never be substituted for conven-
If a brain tumor cannot be cured, treatment is
tional therapy. However,complementary therapies (used
designed to make the patient as comfortable as possible
with,not instead of,standard treatments) can help some
and preserve as much of his neurologic functioning as
patients cope with the stress of their illness and side
possible. The patient’s doctor may prescribe:
effects of their treatment.
•analgesics to relieve pain
Biofeedback can teach patients to influence and
•anticancer drugs to limit tumor growth
control heart rate,muscle tension,and other stress-relat-
•anticonvulsants to control seizures ed body functions.

--- صفحة 593 ---
ial breast cancer cases (families in which there is a high
breast cancer frequency) have mutations affecting the
tumor suppressor gene BRCA-1. Another gene (BRCA-
2) also appears to confer inherited vulnerability to early-
onset breast cancers.

--- Chunk 3365 ---
However, breast cancer due to
heredity is only a small proportion of breast cancer cases;
only 5%–10% of all breast cancer cases will be women
who inherited a susceptibility through their genes. Nev-
ertheless,when the family history is strong for develop-
ment of breast cancer,a woman’s risk is increased.
Not all lumps detected in the breast are cancerous.
Fibrocystic changes in the breast are extremely common.
Also known as fibrocystic condition of the breast,fibro-
cystic changes are a leading cause of non-cancerous lumps
in the breast. Fibrocystic changes also cause symptoms of
pain,swelling,or discharge and may become evident to
the patient or physician as a lump that is either solid or
filled with fluid.

--- Chunk 3366 ---
Complete diagnostic evaluation of any
significant breast abnormality is mandatory because
though women commonly develop fibrocystic changes,
breast cancer is common also,and the signs and symptoms
of fibrocystic changes overlap with those of breast cancer.
Diagnosis
The diagnosis of breast cancer is accomplished by the
biopsy of any suspicious lump or mammographic abnor-
mality that has been identified. (A biopsy is the removal of
tissue for examination by a pathologist. A mammogram is
a low-dose,2-view,x-ray examination of the breast.) The
patient may be prompted to visit her doctor upon finding a
lump in a breast,or she may have noticed skin dimpling,
nipple retraction, or discharge from the nipple. Or, the
patient may not have noticed anything abnormal, and a
lump at an early stage.

--- Chunk 3367 ---
If an uncertainty or a lump is
lump is detected by the mammogram.
found,evaluation by an experienced physician and mam-
mography is recommended. The American Cancer Soci-

ety (ACS) has made recommendations for the use of

mality on examination of the breast. Mammographyhas get annual mammograms after age 40.

GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 580
--- صفحة 595 ---
the axillary node status is the best reflection of possible
widespread disease, these nodes in part or all will be
removed at the time of surgical treatment.
Using the results of these studies, clinical stage is
defined for the patient. This helps define treatment proto-
col and prognosis. After surgical treatment,the final,or
pathologic, stage is defined as the true axillary lymph
node status is known.

--- Chunk 3378 ---
Detailed staging criteria are avail-
able from the American Joint Commission on Cancer
Manual and are generalized here:
•Stage 1—The cancer is no larger than 2 cm (0.8 in) and
no cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes.
•Stage 2—The cancer is between 2 cm and 5 cm,and the
cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.
•Stage 3A—Tumor is larger than 5 cm (2 in) or is small-
er than 5 cm,but has spread to the lymph nodes,which
have grown into each other.
•Stage 3B—Cancer has spread to tissues near the breast,
(local invasion), or to lymph nodes inside the chest
wall,along the breastbone.
•Stage 4—Cancer has spread to skin and lymph nodes
beyond the axilla or to other organs of the body.
Treatment
Surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy are all uti-
lized in the treatment of breast cancer.

--- Chunk 3379 ---
Depending on the
stage, they will be used in different combinations or
sequences to effect an appropriate strategy for the type recurrence. This type of primary therapy is known as
and stage of the disease being treated. lumpectomy,(or segmental mastectomy),and axillary
dissection.

entire breast and axillary contents along with the muscles Currently the necessary extent of the axillary dissec-
down to the chest wall was performed as the lone thera- tion is being questioned. Sentinel lymph node biopsy,a
py,(radical mastectomy).

Adjuvant therapy—Treatment involving radiation, Hormone therapy—Treating cancers by changing
chemotherapy (drug treatment), or hormone thera- the hormone balance of the body, instead of by
py, or a combination of all three given after the pri- using cell-killing drugs.
mary treatment for the possibility of residual micro-
Lumpectomy—A surgical procedure in which only
scopic disease.

Aneuploid—An abnormal number of chromosomes together with a rim of normal tissue.
in a cell.

scattered along the lymphatic system that act as fil-
tissue from a mass or cyst using a needle for micro-
ters and immune monitors, removing fluids, bacte-
scopic examination and diagnosis.

Benign—Not malignant, noncancerous.

Biopsy—A procedure in which suspicious tissue is under the arm or in the chest are a sign that the can-
removed and examined by a pathologist for cancer cer has spread, and that it might recur.

Malignant—Cancerous.

Aftercare
Driving and normal activities may be restricted for
up to one week. Stitches are usually removed in seven to
10 days. Typically, a woman can resume all routines,
including vigorous exercise,in about three weeks. The
Breast reconstruction
scars will be red for approximately one month,but will
fade to their final appearance within one or two years. Definition
Breast reconstruction is a series of surgical proce-

dures performed to recreate a breast.

Breast reconstruction surgery may be performed by inserting an artificial substance,or implant,to replace breast tissue.

--- Chunk 3424 ---
Autologous reconstruction,in which a woman’s own tissues are used,includes the latissimus dorsi flap,where skin and
muscle taken from the back is rotated around to the breast area,and the TRAM flap,in which abdominal fat and muscle are
tunneled under the skin to the breast area.(Illustration by Electronic Illustrators Group.)

--- Chunk 3444 ---
Breast ultrasound
Definition
Preparation
Breast ultrasound (or sonography) is an imaging
Before beginning a monthly BSE,a woman’s breasts
technique for diagnosing breast disease,such as cancer.
should be completely exposed.
It uses harmless,high frequency sound waves to form an
image (sonogram). The sound waves pass through the
Normal results breast and bounce back or echo from various tissues to
form a picture of the internal structures. It is not invasive
Each woman’s breasts has their own normal look
and involves no radiation.
and feel. By completing a BSE each month,a woman can
determine what is normal for her and check for changes
that may arise. A regular pattern of lumpiness in the Purpose
breasts is normal.
Breast ultrasound may be used in several ways.

--- Chunk 3445 ---
The
most common application is to investigate a specific area
Abnormal results
of the breast where a problem is suspected. A palpable
If any changes are noticed during a monthly BSE, lump and/or a lump or density discovered by x ray
such as a new,hard lump in the breast or underarms,a (mammogram) can be further evaluated by ultrasound. It
doctor should examine the area immediately. Other trou- is especially helpful in distinguishing between a fluid-
ble signs that should not be ignored include: filled cyst and a solid mass. It can also identify small
lesions that are too tiny to be felt.

592 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
dnuosartlu
tsaerB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 592
--- صفحة 607 ---
biopsy (as a first step in determining treatment for a lesion
that is likely to be cancerous),and needle localization in
surgical breast biopsy. Biopsies guided by ultrasound have
distinct advantages. The ultrasound guides the needle so
that a lesion can be removed for the biopsy. Patients usually
find that the procedure is less traumatic and more comfort-
able than surgical biopsies. Ultrasound is known for its
accuracy in determining how far a cancerous growth
extends into the surrounding tissue in lesions that cannot be
felt. Biopsies guided by ultrasound are generally less costly
than surgical biopsies.

--- Chunk 3449 ---
Additionally,if the abnormality that
requires biopsy can be seen on both a mammogram and
ultrasound, an ultrasound-guided biopsy is often more
comfortable for the patient as no compression is necessary.
Description
Ultrasound can be done in a doctor’s office or anoth-
er outpatient setting,such as a hospital or imaging center.
The patient removes her clothing from the waist up
and puts on a hospital gown,open in the front. She lies
on her back or side on an examining table. A gel that
enhances sound transmission is spread over the area to be
examined. The technologist then places a transducer,an
instrument about the size of an electric shaver, against Normal results
the skin.

--- Chunk 3450 ---
The images from reflected sound waves appear
An ultrasound examination may reveal either normal
on a monitor screen.
tissue or a benign condition such as a cyst. Ultrasound

sitymay hinder clear viewing of internal structures,and ple cyst with no symptoms,additional treatment beyond

--- Chunk 3451 ---
The examina-
tion may take from 30 to 45 minutes. Most insurance A potentially malignant mass can be identified by

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 593
Breast
ultrasound
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 593
KEY TERMS
Cyst—A thin-walled, fluid-filled benign structure
in the breast.
Ductal carcinoma—A type of cancer that
accounts for as much as 80% of breast cancers.
These tumors feel bigger than they look on ultra-
sound or mammogram.
Fibroadenoma—A benign breast growth made up
of fibrous tissue. It is the most common mass in
women under 35 years of age, and is found in
both breasts in 3% of cases.
A breast ultrasound image.(Custom Medical Stock Photo.

--- Chunk 3452 ---
Infiltrating lobular carcinoma—A type of cancer
Reproduced by permission.)
that accounts for 8% to 10% of breast cancers. In
breasts that are especially dense, ultrasound can
be useful in identifying these masses.
Microcalcifications—Tiny flecks that are too small
to be felt. They are important markers of cancer
that show up on ultrasound and mammogram.
Mucinous (colloid) carcinoma—A type of cancer
that accounts for 1% to 2% of breast cancers.
Resembles medullary carcinoma in ultrasound and
mammogram, but usually affects older women.
Nonpalpable—Cannot be felt by hand. In cancer,
growths that are nonpalpable are too small to be
felt, but may be seen on ultrasound or mammo-
gram.
Papillary carcinoma—A type of breast cancer that
primarily occurs in older women.

--- Chunk 3453 ---
On ultrasound,
this type of tumor may look like a solid or com-
plex mass, or it may show up as solid tissue pro-
truding into a cyst.
Tubular carcinoma—A type of cancer that accounts
for approximately 1% to 2% of breast cancers. Can
appear small on ultrasound or mammogram.

--- Chunk 3459 ---
In extreme cases,if the baby can-
Breech birth not be delivered within a few minutes, the baby might
die. Obviously, it is critical to avoid a breech delivery
Definition with a trapped head.
Breech birth is the delivery of a fetus (unborn baby) Of course,many babies are safely delivered from the
hind end first. Between 3-4% of fetuses will start labor in the breech position. There are certain factors that make a
breech position,which is a potentially dangerous situation.

--- Chunk 3460 ---
breech delivery more likely to be successful: if ultra-
594 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
htrib
hceerB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 594
--- صفحة 609 ---
sound (a technique that uses sound waves to visualize the
fetus) shows that the fetus is in the frank breech position,
the fetus’s head is tucked on its chest,and the fetus is not
big,it is less likely that its head will get stuck.
Among breech babies born after the full nine-month
term,smaller babies usually do better. This is not true for
premature babies. Premature babies are more likely to have
a trapped head because the body of a premature baby is
usually much smaller than his or her head. Premature
babies are generally not delivered from the breech position.

--- Chunk 3461 ---
The risks of vaginal breech delivery can be avoided by
delivering the baby through a surgical procedure (cesarean
section, also known as c-section). For the past twenty
years,cesarean section has been recommended when the
fetus is breech. More recently,many providers have offered
the option of version,attempting to turn the fetus within the
uterus to a head first position before labor begins.
Version is based on a very simple idea. If a fetus in
the breech position does a somersault,it will end up head
down. During a version,the obstetrician tries to make the
fetus do a somersault.
A version should only be done in a hospital,with an
ultrasound machine used to guide the obstetrician in
turning the fetus. The fetus should be monitored with a
fetal monitor before and after the version.

--- Chunk 3462 ---

cians give the mother an injection of medication to relax
abdomen. Another clue to the position is the location
the mother’s uterus and prevent any contractions.
where the heartbeat is heard best. If the fetus’s heartbeat

the unborn baby’s buttocks and head. The buttocks are the heartbeat is best heard above the level of the navel,it
lifted up slightly and the doctor pushes on the baby’s is likely to be breech.
head to encourage him to perform a somersault.

spread or focal the bronchiectasis, and the presence of
other underlying disorders.

Bronchitis
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 597
KEY TERMS
Bronchi—The network of tubular passages which
carry air to the lung and allow air to be expelled
from the lungs.
Cilia—Hair-like projections which line the
bronchial tubes (also present in other areas of the
body). Normal cilia beat consistently, sweeping
the bronchi clean of bacteria, viruses, and mucus.
Colorized bronchogram of lungs—right tree has almost no
structure caused by chronic inflammation.(Mehau Kulyk,
Photo Researchers.Reproduced by permission.)

from the trachea (bronchi).

•to diagnose cancer, tuberculosis, lung infection, or

Description
bronchoscopy, a bronchoscope, is a slender cylindrical
instrument containing a light and an eyepiece. There are There are two types of bronchoscopes, a rigid tube
two types of bronchoscopes, a rigid tube that is some- and a fiberoptic tube. Because of its flexibility,the fiberop-
GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 603
Bronchoscopy
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 603
Instruments used in bronchoscopy procedures.

--- Chunk 3515 ---
(Custom
Medical Stock Photo.Reproduced by permission.)
--- صفحة 618 ---
cancerous cells present in the airways. By using a fluo-
rescent light in the bronchoscope, precancerous tissue
will appear dark red, while healthy tissue will appear
green. This technique can help detect lung cancer at an
early stage,so that treatment can be started early.
Alternative procedures
Depending upon the purpose of the bronchoscopy,
alternatives might include a computed tomography scan
(CT) or no procedure at all. Bronchoscopy is often per-
formed to investigate an abnormality that shows up on a
chest x rayor CT scan. If the purpose is to obtain biopsy
specimens,one option is to perform surgery,which carries
greater risks.

--- Chunk 3516 ---
Another option is percutaneous (through the
skin) biopsy guided by computed tomography.
Preparation
The doctor should be informed of any allergiesand
all the medications that the patient is currently taking. The
doctor may instruct the patient not to take medications
like aspirinor anti-inflammatory drugs,which interfere
with clotting,for a period of time prior to the procedure.
The patient needs to fast for 6 to 12 hours prior to the pro-
cedure and refrain from drinking any liquids the day of
the procedure. The bronchoscopy takes about 45 to 60
minutes,with results usually available in one day. Prior to
the bronchoscopy,several tests may be done,including a
chest x ray and blood work. Sometimes a bronchoscopy is
tic tube is usually preferred.

604 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
ypocsohcnorB
GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 604
Bronchoscope
Bronchoscopy is a procedure in which a hollow,flexible
tube is inserted into the airways,allowing the physician to
visually examine the lower airways,including the larynx,tra-
chea,bronchi,and bronchioles.

--- Chunk 3521 ---
It can also be used to col-
lect specimens for bacteriological culture to diagnose infec-
tious diseases such as tuberculosis.(Illustration by Electronic
Illustrators Group.)
--- صفحة 619 ---

usually treated for associated heart diseases.

1997.
with right bundle branch block (RBBB),the nerve impulse
is conducted slowly or not at all. The right ventricle finally John T. Lohr,PhD
receives the impulse through muscle-to-muscle spread,
outside the regular nerve pathway. This mechanism of

Bunion
characteristic mechanism of failure. In each case, the
nerve impulse is blocked or delayed. Patients with LBBB Definition
may have left ventricular disease or cardiomyopathy.

--- Chunk 3574 ---
A bunion is an abnormal enlargement of the joint
(the first metatarsophalangeal joint,or MTPJ) at the base
Causes and symptoms
of the great or big toe (hallux). It is caused by inflamma-
Left bundle branch block usually happens as a con- tion and usually results from chronic irritation and pres-
sequence of other diseases such as arteriosclerosis, sure from poorly fitting footwear.
rheumatic fever,congenital heart disease,myocardi-
tis, myocardial infarction, metastatic heart tumors, or
Description
other invasions of the heart tissue. Right bundle branch
block happens less often from underlying heart disease.

--- Chunk 3575 ---
A displacement of two major bones of the foot (hal-
lux valgus) causes bunions,although not everyone with
this displacement will develop the joint swelling and
Diagnosis
bone overgrowth that characterize a bunion. One of the
Detection of BBB usually takes place during a nor- bones involved is called the first metatarsal bone. This
mal physical examination. The block shows up as a bone is long and slender,with the big toe attached on one
614 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2
noinuB

end and the other end connected to foot bones closer to
the ankle. This foot bone is displaced in the direction of
the four other metatarsals connected with the toes.

--- Chunk 3576 ---
The
other bone involved is the big toe itself, which is dis-
placed toward the smaller toes. As the big toe continues
to move toward the smaller toes, it may become dis-
placed under or over the second toe. The displacement of
these two foot bones causes a projection of bone on the
inside portion of the forefoot. The skin over this projec-
tion often becomes inflamed from rubbing against the
shoe,and a callus may form.
The joint contains a small sac (bursa) filled with
fluid that cushions the bones and helps the joint to move
smoothly. When a bunion forms, this sac becomes
inflamed and thickened. The swelling in the joint causes
additional painand pressure in the toe.

--- Chunk 3577 ---

618 GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2

GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 618
Classification Of Burns
First-Degree (Minor) The burned area is painful. The outer skin is reddened. Slight swelling is present.
Second-Degree (Moderate) The burned area is painful. The underskin is affected. Blisters may form. The area may have a wet, shiny appearance because of
exposed tissue.
Third-Degree (Critical) The burned area is insensitive due to the destruction of nerve endings. Skin is destroyed.Muscle tissues and bone underneath
may be damaged. The area may be charred, white, or grayish in color.
--- صفحة 633 ---
occupational therapy to keep the burned areas from
becoming inflexible and to minimize scarring.

Diagnosis
Tests that detect decreasing lung capacity during the
workday are used to diagnose byssinosis. Obstructive
Byssinosis
patterns are likely in patients who have had recurrent
symptoms for more than 10 years.
Definition
Byssinosis is a chronic,asthma-like narrowing of the
Treatment
airways. Also called brown lung disease,byssinosis results
from inhaling particles of cotton,flax,hemp,or jute.

--- Chunk 3618 ---
Therapy for early-stage byssinosis focuses on
reversing airway narrowing. Antihistaminesmay be pre-
scribed to reduce tightness in the chest. Bronchodilators
Description
(drugs used to relax breathing passages and improve air
Although inhaling cotton dust was identified as a flow) may be used with an inhaler or taken in tablet form.
source of respiratory disease more than 300 years ago, Reducing exposure is essential. Any worker who has
byssinosis has been recognized as an occupational haz- symptoms of byssinosis or who has trouble breathing
ard for textile workers for less than 50 years. More than should transfer to a less-contaminated area.

--- Chunk 3619 ---
800,000 workers in the cotton, flax, and rope-making
industries are exposed in the workplace to airborne parti-
Prognosis
cles that can cause byssinosis. Only workers in mills that
manufacture yarn,thread,or fabric have a significant risk Smoking, impaired lung function, and a history of
of dying of this disease. respiratory allergy increase a textile worker’s risk of devel-
oping byssinosis. Prolonged exposure makes patients
In the United States,byssinosis is almost completely
wheeze more often and can cause chronic bronchitis. It
limited to workers who handle unprocessed cotton. More
does not lead to permanently disabling lung disease.
than 35,000 textile workers have been disabled by byssi-
nosis and 183 died between 1979 and 1992.

--- Chunk 3620 ---
Most of the
people whose deaths were due to byssinosis lived in the Prevention
textile-producing regions of North and South Carolina.
Eliminating exposure to textile dust is the surest way
to prevent byssinosis. Using exhaust hoods,improving
ventilation,and employing wetting procedures are very
Causes and symptoms
successful methods of controlling dust levels to prevent
Wheezing, shortness of breath, and a feeling of byssinosis. Protective equipment required during certain

GEM -0433 to 0624 - B 10/22/03 6:09 PM Page 622
KEY TERMS
Wheeze—A whistling sound made by the flow of
high-velocity air through narrowed airways.

--- Chunk 3622 ---
Wheezing is a symptom of several respiratory dis-
eases including byssinosis and asthma.
